I really enjoyed the campaign for this game, especially the fighter combat, Not something that has been doing in other games thats for sure. I found the story a little farfetched but believeable. If you are buying for the campaign I can thourghly recommend it. Feels like Mass Effect but Call of Duty Mix to it. Would certainly love the gun play for this in ME. If you are buying for the pvp I can say the Multiplayer is still active in DEC 2018 however the annoying part of people jet packing around with katanas and shotguns can get annoying sometimes. Its very weird to counter something coming out you from the side of a wall, around a corner and jumping down onto you. Not something normally you are used to responding to in fps games. Zombie modes is a DLC nightmare and you have to pay for it. So I will recomemend that Campaign and If you like jetpack Multiplayer this game is for you, Campaign 7/10. 6-8 hours is short.
Worth if you can get it on sale (< $20) for the campaign.
Underrated af

Help i cant join multiplayer i stuck with macth making
The campaign for Infinite Warfare is a major return to form for Infinity Ward. It's easily one of the strongest COD single player experiences on offer, with really cool side missions, a fun cast, and sublime presentation. Boosting into space doesn't get old. Really enjoyed my time with it.
I bought this for the single player campaign which I think was great and what I have come to expect from this franchise.  Good story and gameplay.  Great graphics and sound.  I also even enjoyed the space combat element.  Thumbs up !
Great sci-fi shooter/flyer! The backstory and setting is fascinating and NOT like you might expect from a CoD game.I'm not interested in the multi-player, only the single-player. So I can only speak about the latter.Action is good, although funnelled like any of the old CoD games. The missions are made more interesting by the seamless inclusion of your Jackal space fighter as well as the boots-on-deck action. There's a decent variety of weapons and thus approaches to the maps. The tossables are far more interesting than usual fare--rather than yet another grenade to be ignored you're got seeker bots, drones, anti-grav, remote bot hacking, and yes if you're boring you have grenades.The story and acting are interesting and quality. Some thinking was done. This could have easily been a stand-alone and more lengthy SP title if it weren't for the MP sucking up the resources. So it's a short SP experience--20 hours for me--with side missions that you'll want to do as the main story is terse and doesn't continue open-ended; so do take the side-missions.I'm not one for FPS, mainly because (a) most are MP (ugh) and (b) most are historical lead-throwing escapades...yawn. Not this! This is set in a future where the solar system is somewhat colonized and there's conflict between earth-controlled and break-away colony controlled areas. The space fighter segments are fun too, a major reason I bought this was having seen those being played.Feels like the backstory to The Expanse a bit. Without the weirdness. This is a human conflict.I had ignored this CoD title as yet another WWI or, ugh, WWII product with a focus on past or present navel-gazing. But I caught it on SideStrafe's stream (thanks!) and realized my mistake.I wish more CoD product went this way, since there's real imagination and creativity in this kind of setting and the attendant gameplay. Can hope I suppose.
The worst game ever made i hate it so much i wish id never bought it never buy this game9/10 Audits
Excelent and fun campaign.  If your into Sci-Fi you will love this.

Why everyone so mad about this game ? It felt pretty awesome game.
Very great campaign, lots of action, well done combat and fairly good story.  Probably the most I've enjyoyed of a COD game since modern warfare.  I don't play multiplayer though, so can't say much about that.  8/10.
Actually quite fun. Especially if you hate people and wanna play against bots.I've played every CoD since the demo disk of Dawnville for CoD 1 arrived with my PC Format magazine arrived years ago.I loved it up till Ghosts and kinda got bored of it after then... I stayed away from IW when I saw it was "more CoD" but I picked up the Legacy Edition for the equivalent of $15 recently. Both IW and MWR have insanely fun bots, and I enjoy the movement in IW.As someone who loaths people, the bots are awesome.
The storyline is not very interesting and neither are the characters (except E3N - he's cool). It is similar to many Call of Duty campaigns gameplay-wise, just with some new gimmicks to keep things a little fresh. As a disclaimer, I have not played through the campaign on PC at the time of posting this review but have on console.Virtually no one plays multiplayer on PC. I'm not very surprised though, considering how poor Infinite Warfare's launch was and that it's Call of Duty multiplayer on PC. I have read on the discussions that when players  get into a multiplayer match it usually has hackers. The worst part is that the report button allegedly doesn't help. I played 100 percent hacker-free multiplayer on console some time ago and it still wasn't very good. Maybe I just sucked at the game. Anyway, do not purchase expecting a decent multiplayer experience.Zombies is easily the best mode in the entire game. It takes a more lighthearted approach this time, with the playable characters being stereotypes and the setting being a 1980's amusement park. Licensed 80's music plays throughout the park! But it is hard to hear most of the time, at least with the outdated speakers I currently use. I never really got into zombies mode for other Call of Duty titles, but for some reason IW zombies just clicked. No idea why I've enjoyed it and played it longer than all the others combined, I think it just suited my taste better or something.Contrary to popular belief, Infinite Warfare is really not a terrible game. It's not terrific, but it's not terrible at all. While some parts of it feel bland, you can still tell that some effort (for a Call of Duty game) went into the development. From a singleplayer standpoint, this gets the job done. I would recommend waiting until it goes on sale if you want to purchase it for any reason. I also recommend using an Xbox 360 controller for zombies.
Not a bad Call of Duty I enjoyed playing this game.
Good game !
Beat this on Xbox One when it first came out. Playing through again on PC now. If you go into this game knowing what to expect with no high hopes, you won't be disappointed. Honestly I enjoy every Call of Duty campaign for what they are. Weekend rentals, grab yo' popcorn, interactive Hollywood action flick. This is probably the best COD campaign since World at War or the Modern Warfare games. It at least tries some new things. Giving you control of a space fighter, allowing you to moderately choose what mission to play next, allowing optional/side missions (sadly these are some of the best missions) and adding a few new gadgets. The story is kind of nonsensical at more than a glance (like how the ♥♥♥♥ is Mars capable of that sort of industry and why would they attack Earth like that? It's not THAT far into the future) but it features actually solid character development, decent plot points though nothing unexpected and an actual decent ending that's not all golden rainbows. I don't do Zombies, if that's your thing it's as good or bad as it always is and the multiplayer is as good or bad as it always is. Nothing really new with those. Just keep in mind the game is dead online, hahs been since the second month. As is usual for all modern COD's on PC. Doesn't help the corporate monster of Activision continues to divide up it's small playerbase with half a dozen DLC's that lock you off from the rest of the communitty. If it's on sale, for $20-30 and you get what I'm saying about the campaign then honestly I think it's worth it. Though truly it's probably worth $10-15 really if you're only buying it for the campaign, which you are at this point on PC. I just for some reason found this to be one of those games I actually enjoyed yet not sure exactly why despite it's obvious flaws and my it seems like never ending complaints and gripes about the series and it's usual beats.

RIP Ethan ğŸ˜ªğŸ’”
I'll say it again and again, I don't come for the multi-player, most every COD multi-player is the same. The only reason I come for the campaign is because thatâ€™s the foundation that COD was built on. If you have ever played COD 2, then I'm sure you agree that the single player is where the strength of the series truly lays.	I must say, this is one of the best single player FPS campaigns I have played in a long time. The story is good, the whole Earth vs Mars scenario is simple but makes sense, it plays out really well. And this COD has one of the best collection of casts/performances I have seen in a long time. Whoever came up with the idea for the completely sci-fi driven experience, (to the point it might feel a little familiar to Wing Commander or Mass Effect fans) it must have been a hard sell, because it feels nothing like COD. To that point, I think the publishers answer was â€œhey, really cool, but lets slap the Call of Duty title on it just to be safeâ€�.	With all that in mind, it does play like any COD, running and shooting with the addition of these flight sections. The flight sections play out like Starfox, you are restricted to a 360 space to dog fight or you take control of a â€œrail shooterâ€�. These sections are simple, but still fun and add to the sci-fi element nicely. The level design is also slightly different with a short lived section where you are in charge of the main ship and get to choose your missions. It breaks things up nicely, making the campaign feel a little more lateral, just a little. 	Overall, the small differences mentioned above coupled with the well executed presentation keep things fresh enough to be one of the best Call of Duties out there. Unfortunately, at the time of writing, this game holds a $60 price tag. If you are like me and you buy these titles for the single player, then it will feel way too short to justify without a discount. I enjoyed it that much I almost could recommend it for full price, but again, not enough content. If FPS or sci-fi games are your jam, then keep an eye on it.
Got this a while back with MWR and only just tried it. Ya know what for the amount of hate this game got it's probably the best of all the futuristic ones they released. Fun single player. Didnt play the MP but SP was good.
It's sort of bizzare to me the amount of hate this game received.  Maybe the multiplayer is offensively bad, but I'm here for the single player campaign.  And this is the most enjoyable dudebro military shooter I've played in a long time.There are a few minor rough spots like story/pacing can feel disjointed between missions.  And I wasn't thrilled with the space dogfights here - it seems like they hadn't quite worked out the kinks yet.But I picked it up on sale and I feel like I really got a lot of bang for my buck.
Really good game
Call of Duty Infinite Warfare....its modern call of duty.....end of review. Actually this game despite being the goofy modern jet packing and wall running run and gun game plagued with microtransactions is still enjoyable. What? Yes. You heard me right, it actually fits the setting with the sci-fi future gameplay, so its kind of appropriate....well the pay to win crap isnt but the gunplay is fine for the setting (even though I personally prefer boots on the ground). The singleplayer is the defining part of this game however, in part because the multiplayer is hot garbage, but all the same its one of the better single player campaigns Call of Duty has ever had....(yes I'm serious and heres why). So full disclosure, the story is literally Killzone 1-3 compressed and with less character development (so its good)....no I'm not joking, the story is almost exactly the same....play both trust me. Second the setpieces and design is absolutely beautiful, diverse environments, beautiful graphics, and some definite unique gameplay quirks only possible with a sci fi theme. This brings me to the Jackal combat (small fighter spacecraft), its almost worthy of its own game, its polished, it feels like HawX or something, and the missions are all pretty unique for the spacebattles (best are the hybrid ones). Now for the bad for the story, the villians are the "we are bad hurp derp" kind of cliche and the main character cast is the diverse cast of cardboard cliches and the pacing is disrupted by the "freechoice" Mass Effect style mission selection. All in all though, I have to full recommend this game, yes Call of Duty is dying but.... *puts on sunglasses* DEATH IS NO DISGRACE.  *music cues* YYEEEEAAAAAHHH!!!

This is the first time i learned not to always join some hate or even love bandwagon of something. Say what you want about this game. But, the campaign is absolutely solid from most of the aspects. This is easily one of the longest COD campaign i've ever played and the first that includes side missions which is very creative for a linear game. Sadly the multiplayer is kinda unenjoyable since it's nothing really special. But, the zombie mode is still decent and even greater with your friends. I gave this game 8.5/10 for the campaign alone. At this point i would recommend getting for the campaign only for 67% off. Trust me, don't always follow a bandwagon. You would be sorry.

So first things first, I only played the Campaign. It took me 7.5 hrs to beat on Regular difficulty. I honestly loved it, the aerial gameplay was smooth and gave you just the right amount of control over the jet. I couldn't find any reviews on the campaign itself, but it was outstanding in my opinion. How you feel about this game is going to be completely dependant on what you expect. If you're wanting a traditional COD game you probably won't like it. This is extremely sci-fi and the majority of the game takes place in space. If you're into games like that then it's amazing. The game's description doesn't do much to tell you what it's about, so I'll try to sum it up both with and without spoilers.The game begins on Earth & goes into space pretty quickly. Your main enemy is a martian colony that hates how much earth is free & whatever, and their army is completely diehard. You're just doing your best.Spoiler timeThis game had a ton of feels & the ending was good enough to make me cry. But no game is worth $60.00 lmao so get it on sale.

I only played the single player campaign, to be honest, but I still had fun playing the game.Sure I bought it for 10€/$/Pounds/whatever, but I didn't regret it at all.The campaign was entertaining and pretty solid written for a CoD-Game.Sure it has a lot of pathos and patriotism and the villain is pretty generic, but still, they really tried to make an entertaining story with pretty descent characters.The flight scenes were pretty fun too, even though they were very repetitive (shoot other fighters, shoot fighter Ace, Shoot Cruiser, thats it, end of mission).From a graphical standpoint I can't complain.The Cutscenes look gorgeous, and in-game also.Voice acting and the Soundtrack in general is, with the Gunsounds pretty top-notch, but I expected that from a CoD-Game.They always were pretty distinctive, when it comes to sound, music, and Voice-Acting.All in All, I had a lot of fun playing the SP, and you won't regret it for 10 Bucks, but I would understand, when people paid much more for it and got dissapointed.
Two reasons to get this game: the awesome zombie mode and the campaign.Multiplayer is just dead, so just forget about it.The devs were trying to do something a bit different here, and you've got to commend them for that. The campaign fully delivers on that promise, taking the battlefield to outerspace and includes some unforgettable set pieces. Gameplay-wise it's still Call of Duty, but the weapons are either ballsitic or laser weapons to really mix things up. Also lots of spaceship dogfights. Very cool.Having said that, the Call of Duty purchasing community loves their FPS action in boots-on-the-ground format with little variation, so unfortunately this game will be committed to the annals of history - which is a pity because it has a cool and  interesting campaign, and even more enjoyable zombie mode.I honestly played the zombie mode more than anything else. The SpaceLand map is just an awesome nostalgia blast for anyone who was a kid in the 1980s. Worth the purchase price even just for that really. Activision have included some of their Atari 2600 back-catalogue into a playable in-game arcade - just in case you want to get your "barnstorming" on :)Only real negative is that for some reason my antivirus gives this game hell and I can almost guarantee you will have problems unless you disable your antivirus. Nobody tells you this. Why? oh why?

I did not touch multiplayer in this game, and let’s be honest if you buy COD on PC for multiplayer then you are a dumbass because that player base dies in less than a week. So my positive review is for campaign. I honestly love all COD campaigns for their simplicity and spot on scripted events. I don’t care about story/characters/setting/whatever because come on...its COD, you want all those things? Play Withcer 3 or something. But I must say this campaign is best of them all right next to Black Ops. This game gave me a taste of what a FPS RPG could be if done right (I’m talking side missions and stuff). And I know I said that I didn’t care about character development, but Goodman it did I feel them feels for that Robot guy :'(Moral of the story is buy it cheap for campaign and enjoy but that’s it, anything else is...COD

I picked this game up for $20 during a steam sale and honestly I haven't really cared about Call of Duty multiplayer since Modern Warfare...I picked this up because the campaign seemed generally interesting and honestly I think this is probably one of the better FPS campaigns I've played in a while. The "lol COD sucks" meme squad that trashed this game genuinely missed out on a solid FPS experience, there have admittedly been better FPS campaigns in the last couple of years (Doom, Titanfall 2 and Prey come to mind) but there were a lot of risks taken here and my biggest gripe is that they didn't go further.The space flight is servicable but never reaches the level it should and the ability to set your loadouts for each mission is something I genuinely have enjoyed, especially in the optional side missions that give you a chance to utilize stealth if you so choose. Overall the campaign is a nice mix of The Expanse and Battlestar Galactica that is held back by the fact that it is still trying to be another run of the mill Call of Duty campaign, the risks that the developers took shed light on so many new avenues for this franchise to go from a single player perspective.I'm probably in the minority in that I came to this game for the single player but it is genuinely an enjoyable experience and definitely worth picking up on a sale. I won't vouch for the multiplayer since I personally prefer other FPS games for my multiplayer fix.

IW is one of the most underrated games of all time. Why? Because everyone slams it without legitimately trying it. There was release drama surrounding the game's setting, following the newer "advanced movement" CODs Advanced Warfare and Black Ops 3. Difference here was the game takes place off of earth, a first for the franchise. Along with that fans wanted a return to the series roots. "Boots on the Ground" became a buzzword for hating on IW, and it's trailer became one of the most disliked videos on YouTube. While it still sold well it lead to Sledgehammer Games convincing Activision to take the series back to where it started: WWII. Advanced movement and the futuristic setting lead to the hate, but what about the game itself? Does it function well, does it execute or add anything to the COD format? This is a review of the single player. Multiplayer is a lower point for the series and while Zombies here is fantastic it's not what I'll be focusing on.Gameplay:Most of the game takes place in normal first person like the rest of the series. Two weapons at a time, kill the enemies and move up, but here they spiced up the level design and gameplay a bit. Like IW and BO3 you can double jump, and IW's level design takes this into account. The battlefields you traverse add a lot of verticle leg room allowing you to flank enemies or get to a new vantage point easily take them out. Wanna use your machine gun from behind cover like old CODs? You're welcome to. Wanna jump up to an onning and shoot through a window with a sniper or instead? You have that choice. Like BO2 you can customize your loadout before a mission which is a nice touch. IW has robotic enemies to the mix like BO3 but here they're mostly more human and you'll encounter them more often. What this adds is a layer to combat. Robots are harder to kill with normal ammo, and injuring them puts them in a self destruct mode where they chase you. You can grab different grenade types throughout the missions, some better against robots some better against humans. Make the choice to depending on what you may be facing. Giant robots are also combatants, and they act more as mini bosses. There are also a few anti gravity secions that allow full floating movement but they're few and far between. Outside of the grounded FPS gameplay there are space dogfights. They're handled extremely well, allowing you free movement and a few weapons to dispatch enemy ships. These are really fast paced and satisfying, and they have a non linear feel giving you many objectives at once. Something new to the table here is your mother ship which plays like a HUB. Outside of story missions you get a list of optional missions you can choose to complete if you want. These add a lot of game time to your run, and if you don't want to do them they're optional. You can also get infor on missions, events and characters in your office which is a great touch. Going to a story mission isn't even just selecting it and it starts; you go through the ship talking to team members and getting your loadout before entering your ship to head off to the mission. A great touch that adds immersion to the package.Presentation:The game looks really good and runs beautifully depending on your hardware. Running an i7, 16gb DDR4 and a 1080 and the game runs with almost no hiccups. There was a moment entering the ship before a mission where the framerate went down but other than that it functions flawlessly during gameplay.Music is good but nothing great, just adds a cinematic score to the atmosphere of the situation. Voice talent is perfect though. All the performances are great and give the game personality. Writing is also top notch which we haven't had in an IW game yet IMO. Their plots have always had some major flaws or were overly dramatic but the feeling and weight of the story is perfect here. Nobody is overly written, their dialogue matches the situations they're in, like BO2 there are third pre rendered cinematic cutscenes which helps the storytelling and the cyborg Ethan provides great comic releif and is one of the better characters in the series despite being a robot. Overall presentation is great and adds to the storytelling the most since BO2.Conclusion:Overall it has great gameplay and great production values. It often doesn't feel like COD but more of a new series. It sucks we'll never get a follow up along these lines but this is easily the best of the futuristic CODs going solely but single player. If the multiplayer on offer here was better it'd easily be one of the best of the series. IF you're looking for a great single player FPS to give occasional multiplayer time to and enjoy Zombies you'll love IW.

Call of Duty Infinite Warfare features an amazing campaign which is also touching on an emotional level. You care for the characters.. at least I did. This is what makes this game for me... but.... and there is a huge but...There are still bugs after roughly 2 years that were never fixed and that really have an impact on the gameplay. For example there is a bug which you may or may not encounter during Operation Burn Water where your ship is simply not moving thus ther is no option for you to complete the mission other then A> Starting all over again and Hoping you don't get stuck again or B> load a "third party" save file which skips the mission.Another terribly annoying "bug" is FPS drops during cut scenes. While my pc handles the game and all it's action scenes perfectly at 60 fps the framerate drops immensly during cut scenes (and these are important throughout the story).Overall I highly recommend this game, even with these trial and errors.. however just keep it in mind it may spoil some of the fun.

This game has the most misleading title that fans of this franchise could be easily duped by. At the end of the game  the war is over, So how is this infinite warfare. Each year the call of duty brand does this  insidious marketing scheme to trick fans into buying their new games. Another fine example is Modern warfare, The game has been out for 11 years and 2 months how is that ''modern''As an idiot i can see why fans are fuming with this franchise and why many haven't pre-ordered Black ops 4, Just how are These covert operations in the black ops series  '' Covert'' if Activision markets them publicly. While am at it, Everyone saw the trailers,reviews and played the 2013 released product so how can they have the blatant disregard to call the game ''Ghosts'' .This lunacy has been a persistent problem with this legendary product, Back in 2004 Spark Unlimited released Call of Duty:Finest Hour and fans were disgruntled. When they found out it took several hours to complete. But the most incredulous use of this bamboozling marketing came in 2013 when Activision published Call of Duty : strike team and didnt let gamers play as Wayne Rooney or Cristiano Ronaldo. From that day on fans needed to admit Activision had dropped the ball. Which brings us up to this year  in which Black ops 4 showed us the mystery box .The Mystery Box comes complete with a copy of the game in an exclusive steelbook along a whole host of goodies. These include a comic, a 1000-piece jigsaw, a phone-grip, art lithographsWho the hell is it a ''Mystery'' If we know whats inside of it.Anyways this game is fun and has some new ideas 10/10Signed: a sarcastic twit Thank you for reading

This isn't the first Call of Duty game I've played if you count the ones on DS. I did not expect to enjoy a CoD game but picked it up due to the low price. I got way more than I expected.Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare is CoD in space. Being in space provides more variety than you might otherwise have over the nine hours the game took me to complete. Each mission felt different, preventing the game from becoming stale. Even if this was not for a shift in gameplay it was for the different environments. There's this level on a spinning asteroid, causing a rapid day night cycle. Everything there is powered by light, including killer robots. This means everything turns off every 20 seconds. The proximity of the sun also means standing outside will kill you very rapidly.Shooting the various guns feels adequate though not having a button to swap between your two or three weapons is annoying, only scrolling works. Whenever you get shot the entire screen blurs, this can make encounters with larger amounts of enemies frustrating.This game has side missions! Some are fairly interesting, most of them are just fights in a spaceship. They all feel the same and are set up for spectacle with the lock-on feature, causing the enemy to take scenic routes. This results in enemies often being easier to kill if you ignore the lock-on feature. The problem with these missions is that completing them unlocks upgrades, this includes faster reload speeds and faster health regen. This meant that ignoring them would make other missions more annoying, doing them made the current mission more annoying.I can't say I really remember any of my squadmates aside from the robot. It's hard to feel sad when an underdeveloped character dies. Especially when everyone feels underdeveloped or perhaps just not well written enough.Essentially I would say this: Call of Duty Infinite Warfare is not a great game, but it's an enjoyable one despite this fact.

Hi everyone, I would like to share my gameplay experience on Call of Duty: Infinite warfare. As you can see, CoD: IW is more likely a "future-style" FPS game as well as Black Ops 3 and Destiny 2, this game is mainly featured the warfare in the galatic instead of in Earth. If you are fans of CoD franchise, you will love and enjoy this FPS game. I bought this game is purely for single player campaign and zombie mode. When you play campaign, you will notice that IW also featured high wall run, the fight between player and giant machines, use the jet fighter to invade and destroy the enemies' bases , as well as Black Ops 3.  If you want to reach 100% achievement, then you need to own full base game and season pass. Season pass contained both Multiplayer maps and Zombies maps.But, there is little piece of my mind about review in community. After reading the review, I honestly say IW does not deserved to receive more negative reviews. I have no idea why this game was suddenly contaminated by the wave of negative one, but to me and dare I say to everyone of you, most of negative reviews are totally bullsh!t and garbage!!! If you want to read the review that worth to referred, then look at mine and positive one. I really feel bad to Infinite warfare since they put a lot of heart and effort to make this game. 1) Gameplay: I really enjoy to play the single player campaign, use jet fighter, wall run, fight against the machines, and stealth kill. In IW, you also can customize your weapon and equipment that fit your style. Not only that, but also Zombie game is very challenging mode, if you wish to know how to something work and reach easter egg, go watch youtube as youtube got a lot of guideline. The mechanism of IW zombies is almost same with BO3 Zombies. And the veteren is totally a nightmare, good luck with it. 2) System performance: The video graphics look so nice and decent, what a masterpiece. Optimization was on good condition, never had any problem with FPS, shuttering and crashing.3) Storyline: You can treat this game as the hollywood style movie, at least you understand what the story is talking about. Based on my feeling, this game is little like star wars or Destiny 2. But Infinity ward never changed their style in making the story, there will be always some protagonists will sacrifice during commencing the mission and at the end, same with modern warfare series. 1) Multiplayer : I honestly say multiplayer is completely dead, as not so many people to play this mode anymore. If you buy this game is just for multiplayer then don't buy it.Lastly, if you think the pricing is very expensive to you, add it to wishlist and wait until the next sales. Thank you for reading my review and have an amazing day.
It's COD. So don't expect too much. Unless you like tripping out and cleaving zombies with a double sided axe.
First some background: I have stopped playing Call of Duty games few years ago, bought every single one from first CoD (2003) up to BlOps2, after that I bought Advanced Warfare which was mediocre and after that I promised myself not to buy another one. I have to note that I play only single player part (yeah, I'm old and weird) and don't care for multiplayer. I did grabbed the Infinity Warfare mostly for that MW Remaster recently, and after finishing MW:R I installed IW thinking that I might as well try it. And I have to say I was pleseantly surprised. It was one of the best single player campaigns in CoD games IMHO. I loved the setting, the fact that you could do some side missions, wonder around Retribution, participate in space battles. It felt like modernized version of old Wing Commander games with added FPS elements (I'm still waiting for Squadron 42 Chris!).Overall I feel that the bad marks it get was from all those MP players who were probably oversaturated by the futuristic gameplay in CoD games. Single player part of CoD games is most likely omitted by most these days. Brian Bloom did really good job with the story, which wasn't as short as I thought it would be. There were some really crative setttings for the missions. Also the characters were likeable and mostly unforgetabble, with Ethan stealing the show.TL;DRReally good single player campaign, highly recommended. Get it on sale.For MP part check other reviews.
It is not that bad
In my humble opinion. This is the best COD sp experience by far. The story and characters got me. I am a sucker for sci-fi, but this is very well done. Imagine a smaller scale mass effect without aliens, but with micheal bay.

Few things up front - I bought on Steam Sale and specifically for the campaign.  I am not a CoD fan I don't generally like military themed shooters (no disrespect to the military I used to be in the Army) I prefer fantasy/scifi.  I have not tried multiplayer nor do I intend to.  So why the hell even buy this game?  I really have been wanting a game that combines both ship combat and FPS missions with a good story.  Really hoping games like Star Citizen/Squadron 42 will be good but who knows if those will ever come out.  That said I decided to give Infinity Warfare a shot and the campaign really did scratch that itch at least a little.  The overall campaign was ok.   Hard not to expect AAA graphics from this series so of course the visuals are insane.   The story and characters were decent but a bit shallow.  I absolutely had a blast with the aerial combat and wish there was a seperate mode for that.  The FPS stuff was OK but Titanfall 2 did it better (they both have similar gimmicks such as wall sliding, jetpacks, etc).   All in all I was really enjoying my time but being what it is of course the campaign is super short and it could have been so much more.  The potential is there but sadly it's CoD which means the focus is multiplayer and I assume most of the bad reviews are from the multiplayer crowd.  I would have loved if there were hundreds more side missions.  I would love if the characters had more lines and you can get to know them better.  I would love if you can freely walk around the Retribution (the carrier ship you command).  Oh well.
I only bought this game to play through the campaign and was nothing short of impressed. It was an amazing experience and  I want to thank the devs for making one of the best fps shooter player experiences I have played in a long time.
Quick caveat - I only played the single player campaign, and also picked this up on sale, so reviewing this as a "is this worth $10" vs "is this a triple AAA title".And the answer - for me, it was! The campaign is fun, the shooting has the customary Call of Duty feel which still struggles to be beaten, and the missions are varied and interesting. I actually enjoyed for a change having side missions for their own right, vs being a requirement for getting the "best" ending which happens so often in games. It means they can be played for the reason we're ostensibly here to begin with - to have fun!It's not without its quirks - Kit Harrington has been cast as the bad guy in possibly the weirdest choice in history, given he doesn't really have the gravitas to carry off the role of a mass murderer/do anything to win type individual. As many have commented, the campaign is fairly short too, making it worthwhile for a long afternoon's play, but not something to really get your teeth into.I'd have loved a longer campaign, and to flesh out characters more who were on the cusp of becoming interesting. Also, I'd probably thumbs up for Ethan (the robot) alone - very well written and stands out amongst a fairly generic crowd. It's a shame that IW chose to underinvest in this, as I suspect the game may have been considerably more popular if they'd given the campaign the attention it deserved. The setting (kind of a Battlestar Galactica crossed with The Expanse) is a popular genre right now, and probably could have carried it to an audience beyond the usual crowd.If you have the chance to pick this up on sale, and enjoy tight shooters with a novel campaign, you could do a lot worse than dropping $10 or so on a pretty good afternoon's worth of fun.
Thought to buy this game many times but bunch of negative reviews had stopping me. Bought this game on summer sale and was pleasantly surprised. Don't know why it has so many negative. Story short but pretty interesting. Gameplay same as in other CoD games. Same multiplayer. After first completion new difficulty is opened which what i looked for. If you like storytelling and want to shoot some bad guys in isolation of reality it is good game. If you play games for new gameplay types, new mechanics, if you see CoD franchise only in WWII or modern time this game is not for you.
Just completed the single player campaign and I loved it. Great story, fantastic gameplay and incredibly memorable charcters. I saw a lot of negative reviews which discouraged me from buying it until the steam sale where I think I got it for $20 - 30 range. Completely worth it for the experience and highly recommended especially if you enjoy military space stories like the Expanse or BSG. Ethan is one of the best characters that COD has written and the ability to take part in ship to ship combat is just brilliant. Disclaimer: I have not played or intend to play the multiplayer or zombies mode but for the single-player alone BUY THIS GAME!!

I honestly dont think this game deserves the reviews it has recieved. Imo, this game had one of the best singleplayer campaigns I have played in a long time. This game conveyed so much emotion and character devopment, it didnt feel like a call of duty. All in all, the story gets a 10/10 from me.Moving on to zombies. The willard wyler production theme is different. I do have the season pass (so this is regarding all of the maps) They have a lot of contrast, each one is very unique. I do wish you could play out ridiculous round grinds without the mini bosses, but their difficulty is part of what makes these maps so fun. They went overboard with the eastereggs, insanely intricate. But none the less, quite special. All in all, the zombies mode gets a 8/10.Last and unfortunately least, the multiplayer. I think this mode generally has the least depth of all of the modes, but none the less, it is always fun obtaining all of the weapons, then starting over so you look cooler than everyone else. I think you get where im coming from with that one. Its very pretty, and the jets make for a new interesting challenge for killing other players. All in all, multiplayer gets a 7/10 from me.One other thing. The fact that you can unlock weapon variants by using keys (a little slow and agonizing, probably so you'll buy cod points) but the guns you can obtain add interesting and uniqe advantages. For instance, you can literally weild a minigun styled lmg in akimbo. (Unlocking them for multiplayer aslo unlocks them for zombies as well, very much appreciated.) This is one of my favorite COD titles to date. I own the franchise pack all the way up to WWII, but i have to say i play this one more than any other. All in all, 9/10.
FYI - I do not play multiplayer (nor will I ever), nor am i a graphics junkie...Ignore the twitchy teenagers complaining about this game because the multiplayer sucks. I don't know if it does, and I don't care.Campaign is awesome - although story is a bit sci-fi generic (see: The Expanse) but game play is rock solid and a hell of a lot of fun. Great plot, great characters, and some fantastic new ways of solving challenges (loved the hacking, drones, etc.). Loved the zero-G levels, loved the stealth, and love the Doom16 run and gun levels - even the Jackal space fights are a good laugh.All in all, everyone needs to chill out, this game is about as good as FPS' get - and prob the second best COD game. Only complaint I have is the campaign a bit short (i took my time and got 13h)Techwise, runs like a dream on 1060 6GB 1080P all on ultra. not a single hiccup.So enjoy, Infinity Ward have nailed it - atleast as good as Doom16 and Wolfenstein16's campaigns, so ignore the spammy negative reviews from tantrum teens - and enjoy while on Steam sale.

I got Call of Duty Inifinite Warfare on sale during the steam summer sale for just under 20 dollars. At that price point, this game is absolutly worth buying just for the single player experience.I had always been curious to try the campaign in infinite warfare because of the fantastic trailers, but I was afraid that the games best moments were all showcased in the trailers. To my surprise, the campaign has a ton of great moments that were not already shown.Everything from fireing a giant laser gun to driving a car out of a spaceship. The story is prety straight forward (The bad guy attacks, so you retaliate), but the characters are likeable and their interactions have a suprising amount of heart. All in all, the single player campaign is very fun, and this is a worth while sci-fi shooter. If you are buying it for the single player, and you can get it on sale then I would recomend Call of Duty Infinite Warfare.

“Ok. Let me just do what is needed first.” Shoves multiplayer into a dark room where Black Ops III’s campaign and Advance Warfare’s Zombies are. “And don’t come back you hear!” Now this game is not actually bad if you were to remove the multiplayer out of it. Even if then it technically its not its fault either. Well kinda. Its just that it came out at a really bad time since there was fatigue after the 2 previous installments were both set in the future. If this game had came out before Treyarch’s game it probably would have been a different outcome. The campaign of this game is probably one of my favorite Call of Duty campaigns and its a very big improvement over Black Ops III’s story (Train goes boom). Set in the year 2100 or later (best guess since they don’t say date) where the Earth is very low on resources and relies on traveling to different planets and moons to gather those resources. Unfortunately they no longer have the ability to because it has been cut by the main enemies in the game the Settlement Defense Front (SDF) whos main goal is to conquer the entire Solar System and destroy all Earth born humans. You play as Nick Reyes the now leading commander of the United Nation Space Alliance. You will travel around from planet to planet liberating them from the SDF. There are missions where you either fight on the surface the traditional way or in space in where you will be having space. I guess I have to address the elephant in the room. Its decent but mostly meh. Jumping all over the place, wall running you get the idea. Its basically III’s multiplayer but with less specialists, with new ones kinda. Map designs are all right but one thing for sure that I liked from the game was the fact they added fun variation game modes like Gesture Warfare which is extremely fun. Sadly, other than that, multiplayer got really boring and repetitive after a while.I will be talking about the 2 maps that I played, Zombies in Spaceland and Rave in the Redwoods. I found Infinity Wards take on Zombies to be pretty good actually. Fun maps to play on. Perks have different names but basically have the same effects as the ones from Treyarch Zombies. What really makes this much better is that once you beat the main Easter Eggs for each of the maps you can play as the celebrity that cameos in the map like Kevin Smith (oh my) and David Hasselhoff (holy sh*t).This game deserves a chance to be played in my opinion. Obviously the multiplayer is gonna be dead but everything else is worth playing. Having the best (in my opinion) campaign out of the 3 exo/advanced movement games and pretty good zombies experience I say buy it if you want at full price but you can wait for it to go down during a sale.8/10
The most surprising part of playing the game was that I forgot that it was a Call of Duty game. There are the regular tropes littered about, but between the Space Ace Combat flying, the side missions, the zero-gravity gunfights and proper science fiction aesthetic, I genuinely got lost in the world of Infinite Warfare. Occasionally, a cutscene where I would lose a fight to an engineer or be bad guy that I wouldn't be allowed to kill myself would jerk me back to reality, but the fact that it let me lose myself for a little while shows how much an environment and gameplay change can benefit a stale series.

I bought the 6-disc PC version, but run it through Steam.NOTE: I was one of MANY people who encountered problems running COD:IW, where it froze, wouldn't load, had to run in safe mode & again wouldn't load Mission 1. But... PROBLEM FIXED!! Go to your antivirus software and put your Steam folder in the 'Exceptions' list, and then the game should work fine.I usually can't play anything in 1st person, but I played COD:IW for a few hours with no sickness whatsoever. Be warned though, there's no 3rd person camera angle.Great graphics, top-notch voice acting and good script.Well worth every penny so far.

Following the post modern warfare 2 debacle, it became cool to hate cod like hating nickelback was cool. After having finished the modern warfare series I vowed never to touch another cod piece. I acquired infinite warfare in the purchase of the mw1 remaster. Only wanting to play the latter, I had zero expectations going into inf warf. What ensued was completely surprising. This game is the epitomy of a fast paced action adventure FPS set in a sci-fi universe. I have to admit, I played this game coming off of a BattleStar Galactica binge watch, so my opinion may be a bit biased. Now with the Expanse, I'll definitely be reinstalling this. The Expanse (tv show) is a great compliment to this game. They're very similar minus the alien bit.The space battles were funner than I expected. Well calibrated for mouse and keyboard. The story isnt anything special, but neither was HL1's. They really kept that aspect simple.Worth playing at 20-30$. Skip the multiplayer though.

I know everybody and their mommas gotta hate on CoD cause the devs keep it a FPS, oh lord, how lazy and evil /s but this time around it's extreme, "mostly negative"? for real?DISCLAIMER: I ONLY PLAYED THE SP CAMPAIGNThe SP Campaign is one of the best and longest CoD has ever had. I've played the original CoD, BO, BOII, AW, MWIII...now it's established among every single CoD hardcore player that "MWII has had the bestest campaign and it's the best shoota and wow *♥♥♥♥ everywhere*"and thus my opinion on this whole subject is null to all of those, for the rest of the ppl reading this:- there are not only human enemies, but also bots, which are weak to energy weapons- tiny but fine system of weaknesses, see above- quite enjoyable space battles (in ships, not only on foot)- alright graphics, runs good on not so highend hardware- they put lots of effort into details like missions logs, background talk, extra audio etc.- campaign is one of, if not the best, of all CoDs (haven't played the WW part tho), def the best futuristic one- voice acting is mostly above average- some relatively open levels- nice variation of the environment (Earth, Mars, Asteroids etc)- not many QTEs!negative stuff:- I didn't find wallrunning to be effective..uhm...or even possible in most locations? I burned out on CoD a long time ago in the dark ages and haven't played one since, but I have to say I'm really enjoying the campaign in this one. I love the near future aspect where the solar system has been colonised but interstellar travel doesn't appear to be a thing yet. All of the space sequences, whether dog fighting in fighter craft or reviewing missions or personnel records on the cruiser gives me a massive Wing Commander vibe and that's awesome because it's been too long since there's been anything like it. I don't do multiplayer, I can't speak to that, but the campaign is a lot of fun.
First off I will say this, I have absolutely no interest in any multiplayer aspect of the CoD games. As such, this is only about the campaign. Of all the CoD games I've played, this has got to be one of the best. The campaign is pretty damned good. The story is grand and feels as if you really are the underdogs, and considering what happens at the beginning, that's no surprise. The charactes are well done, I especially love E3N. Unlike most CoD games, at the end of this one, I felt satisfied. The flight sections really help to break up the tedious gun fights that drag most CoD games down with their repetitive nature. I really don't see why this game was hit so negatively, except that is isn't an old war people fight in (why they'd want to play the same thing over and over and over just with better graphics, I don't get it). I feel as if this is the first game that if they made a TV show of it, it would be good. I don't mean that becaue of the cutscenes, they are nice though (when the audio sync up correctly). Pretty much every CoD game I've played, I've finished in 4-5 hours. I got nearly 11 hours out of this one, and it was worth it. I really wish they'd take what they did with this game and expand on it, even if they didn't continue the near future setting.

I like the Campaign and the Zombie modes but I hate the multiplayer mode. I got it for free thanks to a Garry's mod server, so I can't complain, but hmm...Decent.
Don't buy into the hate; this is a stellar game.I do understand a lot of the initial anger. Because of the decision to pair this game with the remastered MW2, the entire game functions as a hard paywall. That is a very difficult thing to overcome. But honestly, this game is magnificent. The story is one of the finest in a COD game, with themes and characters that are truly meaningful. It's all action, all the time, but the throughline is so much more immersive than prior games. You are with your one character the whole game, and you are getting to know and care about your command, your ship, and your friends. The space combat is truly *fun.* Flying your ship through epic space battles feels genuinely cool. The optional missions are varied, and present really innovative scenarios: stealth your way through an enemy warship and remain in camoflage, then fight back through after you've gone loud; sneak up on an unwitting capitol ship from space, picking your way stealthily through an asteroid field as you take out patrols of enemy personnel. There's a lot going on in this game that are new for the series, and they're almost all executed very well. Your character being the captain of the ship was an interesting and ultimately excellent choice. Your ability to command the ship, choose your next mission, use your captain's quarters, and watch videos with the crew presents a Mass Effect-lite type off-mission experience. Your ship itself is modelled fabulously, with everything really feeling like a working ship of war. And when you're off your ship looking at it, you really feel like you know it, its crew, its halls. But what really brings this game together is the story. Again, it's fantastic. The ending is emotionally raw and powerful. The final battles are dripping with the kind of climactic intensity and adrenaline-soaked desperation that is so rarely done this well. The voice acting is absolutely top notch. And when it all comes together, if you're willing to take it seriously, you come out of the story really thinking about what you learned about service, sacrifice, and soldiering. You can feel your main character changing over the course of the game, and it feels like a very personal experience. My only real complaint is the "bad guys" in the game are comically evil, somewhere in the Darth Sidious school of antagonism. But really, it doesn't matter. If you're willing to give this game a shot, I think you will be very impressed with the production value, the experience, and the story. One of the best COD's I've ever played.
Easily the best game I've played in this genre regarding singleplayer campaign.

Just speaking for the campaign here - the multiplayer is terrible.  One of the best COD campaigns since MW3, flawed only by the writer's naivety to try and force some serious themes into the plot when you're blowing up space warships, becoming best buds with AI, and putting up with Jon Snow knowing nothing. No spoilers here, it would have worked had the player been given the option of choice, but you never do. Instead you'll watch your character lose all of his skill during clinch moments and then have the game try and tell you to watch the consequences of your actions, even though you've been singlehandedly taking on armies up until this point. Regardless, it is a cinematic, fun, reasonably lengthy (for cod game - 10-12 hours on veteran doing all the side missions), thrill ride that looks amazing. Worthwhile finishing over a weekend for some good shooty shooty bang bang. I would buy it on sale though.

I was getting a little tired of CoD being set in the future, but I realized that if this game was some new IP it would be considered a great game. Is there room for improvment? Absolutely. The story, as with most CoD stories, requires no thought. Alternative routes and even a branching storyline would have taken this game to another level. Character development was better than recent games, but it still hasn't been able to get close to characters from the Modern Warfare trilogy. In the end, this is one of the better Call of Duty games. It has the same big flaws that most Call of Duty games have, but the overall experience is much more enjoyable.

ONLY SP review!Wow - a really good futuristic COD! I lvoed the cutscenes, the gameplay and the missions. It reminds me a lot of the tv show the Expanse. What i disliked is the story... So many plotholes and dumb Deus ex Machina
This game has definitely recieved alot of hate but you can somewhat understand why....Singleplayer: The story is very well written and i enjoyed the campaign, the only thing i can say though is its very short which was quite a dissapointment but if you take time to do side quests it will lenthen it by an hour or so.multiplayer: The multiplayer will take some a while to get used too as its very fast paced and because the maps are rather small camping in corners won't last very long. There is a vast array of guns, setups etc but the supply drops is where this game has a downfall , so instead of earning skins its kind of a pay to get. Cod points are expensive and its a luck of the draw as to what you will get in a supply drop but i have to be honest i have recieved some great things through epic supply drops. Guns are reasonably balanced apart from shotguns which are extremely overpowered which kind of ruins the fun for everybody. Maps are small with a three lane format but it isn't just a few smalls map, pretty much every base map is small besides terimal which is a reskin anyways. The DLC maps however are much much better and some should of been put on the base game but nevermind its just one of those things i suppose. In my opinion the multiplayer is the weakest part of this game although can still be fun in short bursts.Zombies: Easily the strongest part of this game, zombies in spaceland is an absolute blast and one the best maps i have ever played in zombies. The new fortune cards add some variety to playing and some can be very useful in later rounds where the pace picks up. Optimization: Compared to black ops 3 this game runs alot better but you will still need a card with 4GB v-ram to enjoy on high settings. CPU wise it doesn't use very much which was surprising considering how fast paced it is but please make sure you have 12-16 GB of ram if playing on over medium settings as its does use a fair bit.

It may be a bad CoD Game, yet it's a damn great Science Fiction Shooter.A bit short though, but I've had lots of fun.
If you enjoyed the previous CoD games campaigns then ignore the haters, you should play this game. If that is not enough to convince then read on.I loved the SP campaigns of the MW trilogy, played all the other CoD games except last WW2, Ghosts and BO3. The formula had grown tired, the gameplay and stories repetitive. I got Infinite War cheap and decided to try it despite all the fanboy rage around the trailer. IW is by far the best CoD game graphically, gameplay, stability, and story wise.I have played this game from beginning to end without a single bug, glitch or crash. It is the most stable and smooth running CoD game ever, ignore the many negative reviews that say otherwise. Maybe it was more buggy on release, I don't know, but it is perfect now. The action is your usual CoD fare but some new weapons and grenade types give it a more fresh feel than AW did.Moving, jumping, boosting, even vehicle use is far more fluid and easy than previous games, particularly Advanced Warfare which was very clunky and awkward in places.Graphics are the best so far, not surprising since it is the latest game. The visuals, backdrops and scenery are stunning and, as overused as the word is, genuinely epic. The surroundings moving through ships, habitation, buildings etc. are also well done and not as bland and repetitive as previous games.The storyline is the best so far. The acting, dialogue everything easily surpases all previous CoD games, there are also some pretty big names on the voice cast. IW gets you far more emotionally invested with great payoff. It moves along more fluidly, no more static end of level/next level screens. The game has a far more cinematic feel and the cut scenes are engaging, well scripted and acted.Most of the hate in the negativce reviews are clearly from people who decided they hated it and never played it the moment they saw the futuristic setting in the trailer. Many other state the campaign was too short, they got stomped in MP (really? never played a CoD game before?) or there were bugs and most absurd of all one person claimed its graphics were bad. I have not played MP, anotther source of hate, but after reading other forums I get the impression that the negativity is again unfounded and based on innacurate views by people who haven't tried it. Would I pay â‚¬50+ for IW? I wouldn't pay that for any CoD game but I would pay more for IW than any of the others.
Bought it cheap on sale for SP only and besides CoD being CoD with all the stuff that never changes I actually enjoyed this one. i hated advanced warfare but I felt like this is an improvement in terms of story, gameplay and mission design. Even the flight mechanics did somehow work for me and felt fun.Can't talk multiplayer, never tried it, will be as lame and stupid as every other CoD MP only with future stuff. Oh and most likely you can also shoot zombies and stuff...
With all of the DLC installed, this is easily the best COD game in recent years. The campaign tells a stellar story (excuse the pun) with amazing visuals and some really fun level design. The levels set exclusively in space - be it in your ship on assaulting an enemy cruiser - make use of some of the best controls for a space game I've seen to date, and cannot be faulted. The score for the game is also spectacular, but I won't get into that in too much detail.The multiplayer definitely isn't everyone's cup of tea, but will be right up your alley if you enjoyed Black Ops 3's MP. I, personally, didn't get into it as much as I have in past games (I only made Prestige 1 or 2, I cannot remember), but all I have are good memories. Finding matches can be a pain at non-peak times (especially in DLC maps), but when you do get into a lobby you're gonna have a good time. The rig system of class customisation is similar to BO2 & 3's Pick 10 system, but it doesn't feel anywhere near as restrictive (as you can change your rig on the fly in game instead of being limited to one specialist player for each game). Maps are varied in size and layout, some better than others, with a few nice remastered classics thrown in. Gunplay is similar to Black Ops 3, but a little slower paced.Zombies is where Infinite Warfare shines brightest though. The on disk Zombie map - Spaceland - is an absolute hoot, with bright lights, a killer soundtrack and a nice lighthearted spirit that's been missing from a lot of recent Zombies maps in other games. Spaceland is easily the best "base" zombies map since Kino Der Toten in Black Ops. The DLC maps are all radically different, and all knock it out of the park. The addition of the easter egg challenges that had started to get on my nerves by the end of Black Ops 3 was initially a turn-off for me, but all the Infinite Warfare ones feel like something new and rewarding - new characters, modes & customisation items, to name a few.I firmly believe that this game deserves nowhere near as much hate as it received on launch, and will go down in a lot of players' memories as a high point in the series.

This is one of the best games I have played, certainly one of the very top shooters I have played. The story was great (and I do love a good story), the graphics were awesome, the voices realistic, and the mechanics well designed. The sci-fi, futureistic theme made it a lot better (I don't enjoy old war games), and an instant buy for me being on sale. Story is not very long; you'll spend 8 hours on it, but it is well worth it. Great, great game. Really enjoyed it. Now I am enjoying Multiplayer and Zombies.

I got this for 15 Euros so this review is based on that amount of money. I only played the single player campaign on HARD.This game has everything you can expect from a Call of Duty game. Good graphics and animation, good music and voice acting and overall a good story. But its plagued by linear maps, decent scripted events and one of the most horrible enemy AI I have ever seen.The AI is exceptionally bad and can at times really destroy your flow. "" ( Most ) "" enemies will just stay at one single location, never moving even if they are getting shot at. And if you peek out you will get shot with 100% accuracy by 4 targets. So most battles consist of quickly kill 1 or 2 then duck back in and self heal up and do the same over again. You can also throw grenades and other stuff if you have them. This game is probably more streamlined at Normal with less frustrating moments.I also did not like the ending and how some of the main characters was handled. I understand that war is hell and soldiers and civilians will die but some of the sacrifices was badly timed and unnecessary.+ Graphics, Animation and Level Design.+ Music and Voice Acting.+ Some memorable characters, especially Ethan.+ Space battles.+ Overall good story.- Poor endning.- Linear maps.- Bad Ai.- Most weapons are the same. ( I did only use 2-3 in the end )- Some supporting characters could have been handled better.- 70Gb download, 100 Gb installed.So at 15-20 Euro I could recommend this game. Wait for a sale or buy a steam key at another place.

Playing Infinite Warfare was quite enjoyable, even for me – a person who was never a fan of this franchise. Or maybe that’s the reason why I had so much fun?I take games as they are, and just like them or not - without thinking about their biggest adversary, and checking how they look at one wall with other titles from the entire franchise. I am too old and too smart for this infantile stuff, but I understand that very high precentage of humans are idiots. Single player campaign is an excellent piece of art, and one of the best space opera in hard Sci-Fi setting I've seen in last years. Even the game ending (I've seen people complaining about it) is a quintessence and successful tribute for classics of the genre.What this game can offer is deep and solid universe which will amaze you, melted together with well written story and charismatic, emotional characters who you will remember for a very long time. And soundtrack for Infinite Warfare will give you thrills, especialy in emotional scenes.Call of Duty went into space to reach the stars - literally. I hope a sequel will be made, in order to expand this glorious game.

Very good game
Disclaimer: I don't care about multi-player or Zombies, this review is purely for Infinite Warfare's single-player campaign.Absolutely phenomenal!- I love the semi-realistic sci-fi space setting, there's a surprising ammount of depth to this universe (no pun intended). It seems like the devs worked extra hard to make sure the tech in this actually feels practical and usable, which is always a plus in anything really, interactive or not (Alien, Blade Runner, Star Wars for example).- The game's surprisingly well written, not only on a character level, but they also did a fantastic job with the world building and setting.- The gameplay can be separated into three parts: Ground combat, Zero G Combat and Space Combat. All three of them are genuienely enjoyable, the controls are super tight and responsive, and they really help to separate this game from other CoD titles. It's just a blast to play.- Looks great, sounds great and runs great. - Sidequests! I love this game. It's one of the most fun shooters I've played in a long time and by far the best CoD game I've played since the original MW. * This is totally unrelated to IW, but why can't I just buy the campaign separately? And why are their discounts on Steam so ♥♥♥♥ing bad? I love this game, but I totally get why it didn't do well on PC. Your MP servers are a total mess at launch, your business practices are asenine and anti-consumer and your discounts are absolutely atrocious. What are you doing Activision???

"Don't judge a book from it's cover."
Having played all previous Call of Duty games, except for Advanced Warfare, I have to say that this one has my favorite campaign.  It's got the feel of shows like Space Above and Beyond, Battlestar Galactica, and The Expanse.  It's also got a great cast to go along with it who make the characters believable and lifelike.  The set pieces are all fantastic too, with action taking place all around the solar system, from Mercury to Pluto.  I can tell that the writers and designers for this game are science fiction fans, as there are a ton of little details, as well as big concepts, straight out of Isaac Asimov and Arthur C. Clarke novels.Call of Duty has always had some somewhat sketchy vehicle moments, but the space combat segments in this game are Vvastly improved over the aircraft bits we've seen before.  There are also several zero-g combat sequences that I feel were done well.  I also enjoyed the weapons and loadouts, there's a lot of stuff we haven't seen before here, a lot of hybrid weapons, a lot of multifunction weapons, and a bunch of fun gadgets like drones, exploding robots, and a variety of grenades... and one of the nice things is that you can take four types of gadgets and grenades.  You can also customize your Jackal (your air and space fighter), with various machine guns, cannons, tech upgrade, and nose art.This is what Black Ops III wishes it were, and Infinite Warfare took the redeeming parts of Black Ops III and incorporated and improved on them, such as the freedom of movement, wall running, and jumping.  It's also way more optimized... I had to sacrifice a lot of visual quality, in Black Ops III, to get playable performance, but I was able to crank up the settings in Infinite Warfare to the max.  Not only did it look better, it perfromed better... no plastic faces, no crappy lighting, no stuttering and FPS drops.I have no opinion on multiplayer or zombies... that's not why I play these games, and that's also the source of the vast majority of negative reviews that Call of Duty games get, including this one.  My only complaint, which is the same complaint I have for all Call of Duty games, is that I wanted the campaign to be longer.  Hope it gets sequels.

He is very good, gamelay is awsome, graphics are beautifull, atmosphere is great too, characters are  interesting  (ethan is awsome) and it become even emotional towards the end.Multiplayers is great too if you have no problem with slide, wallrun, dash then this game is for you. Don't buy it at full price if you hesitate and do it at least for the campain if you love COD campains like me.There is maybe one bad thing about this game, you will maybe encounter problems with your nvidia or amd parameters but you can find how to resolve this problem in the community guide section of the game. I had this problem first time i tried to play but now it's ok. Anyway it's a great game !
Campaign only review - don't care about the multiplayer so who knows.Surprisingly great game! I went into this thinking it would be bad based on the reviews. Actually the campaign is awesome. The gameplay is pretty diverse (you've got cover based shooter and arcade flight sim / dogfighting) with modifications like space, moderately low gravity etc, the universe is deep, and the artwork is fantastic. The game runs pretty well too. Of course the villains are cartoonishly evil but that shouldn't be a surprise at this point. I'd say almost as good as MW2, better than Advanced Warfare or MW3 or any CoDBLOPS. Is it worth 60? Maybe. 30? Yes.
its the best game
tl;dr If you like scifi, FPS games, and running on walls, this game has you covered.I bought Black Ops III at a massively reduced price, having heard the campaign took some interesting twists and turns, and wanting to experience the frenetic jump-around-everywhere run-and-gun multiplayer that's been in place since Advanced Warfare. Suffice it to say, on every level, Black Ops III was a disappointment, from it's bland graphics and art direction (and performance!), bizarre pacing in the campaign, and terrible level design which did not suit the game's wallrunning and dashing mechanics at all.I heard someone praising the campaign of Infinte Warfare, and decided that it intrigued me enough for me to pick it up instead.I didn't really follow the hype/disappointment following Infinite Warfare's release, but I can't really see what all the complaints are about. The graphics are gorgeous, with colorful and varied visuals, and solid performance, especially in multiplayer. The multiplayer maps, aside from remakes from MW2, are obviously designed with the movement in mind, and are a great place to stretch your legs and use the game's mobility to its maximum potential. Wallrunning never gets old. And as an added benefit, the setting is fantastic. It almost reminds me of a mix between Ghost in the Shell and Halo, with really inspired weapons and weapon mechanics, like an assault rifle that transforms into akimbo SMGs. 10/10But the campaign. The campaign is just incredible. Really amazing performances by the voice cast, the writing is snappy and punchy without being too campy or tryhard, and the pacing is spot-on perfect. You're no longer a lone wolf taking on hordes of enemies- finally we have another COD campaign that focuses on teamwork and unity, with characters that aren't super developed per say, but definitely likeable. Yes, there are 'epic setpieces,' with the first proper level after the intro showcasing a city being destroyed, but it's followed by a /spaceship battle/ that lets you have full control over your craft in a lite space combat sim, and then? A moment of calm. You save your space carrier, board it, and take a breather. One mission later, you're given the freedom to tackle the main missions or multitudes of sidemissions are your discretion.Ultimately, this was a great purchase, and I am super happy I decided to go with it.
Most people complain about the mp so don't pay attention to those reviews if you're in it for the sp. Even if you're not, you should, because it's spectacular. Amazing graphics, sharp writing, characters with personalities you care about, simple but satisfying gameplay, and very high quality acting. This is the first game since the Xbox One generation for PC that I've really said, "this is the next gen". I played it on a 760 originally and the performance:quality ratio was so good despite averaging like 40 fps that I had to finish the campaign immediately. I had a rule against letting technical slackery slide because it eventually infuriates me but I immediately voided it for this game. At the time of writing this I have a 1070 coming in the mail and this is going to be one of the first games I return to on my new rig. Just thinking about how blown away I was on my relatively poor rig with low settings and very undesirable input lag for a fast-paced, reaction-based shooter, I can't even imagine how great the return experience is gonna be in max settings at 60hz. Don't listen to the reviews, if you like military culture, sci-fi, action-adventure shooters, Sorkin-like dialogue, and joyous PC eye candy, you'll love this game. If you can get it on sale for less than 20$ like I did, you're going to get one hell of a bang for your buck. However, looking back, I would have paid full price.
This is an average game. It deserved the negative attention when it came out with them locking Modern Warfare behind this game. Now time has passed and the crowds have moved on, I am getting it now. Mainly because after playing other good games that leave me drained, I just want something that offers a lot of shooty-shooty bang bang without frustration of other people or something that requires a lot of focus.Its average. For the CoD formula, its what you expect. The sci-fi geek in me did enjoy exploring the aspect of space combat in the form of infanty vs infanty in the vaccum of space. Interesting to see just how deadly it could be, where a few stray shots could easily spell doom for many as they are sucked into space. Would love to see other games expand on this to give the feeling of the emptiness of space and how helpless we can be in it without our tools.Campaign is a meh. I didn't like many of the characters, no real attatchment to any of them. The only one that I did enjoy the company of was Ethan. The robot. Uncanny valley is in effect here.I don't touch multiplayer, so that is getting neither a minus or a plus from me.The zombies mode is fun. Different maps, different enviroments, different objectives. Good fun to be had. The downside comes at the expense of no mod maps, which I feel hurts this big time. They could of easily had it that the characters jump from movie to movie to escape but eh... What are you gonna do?In total, I give this an above average meh. So a positive. Recommend getting it when it is on sale. Just get it for those days where you just wanna shoot things without thinking too much.

Step aside. Hacker here.What you need to do is disconnect to SVU control module with a locktan USB. This should protect the connectors on the QSDR board and salvage the PNP relays. After that, extracting the data from the OCSI dongle you can remove the back cover revealing the jupiter translator module. This exposes the THPR connector. There's two small ORYTP ribbon connectors that you'll want to remove and then insert a YPTX base module to. This allows your BTMX systems to run on a SFOPR mode that won't utilize that... eh... toasted hardware. The firmware from the DPXT module will transfer to the locktan USB and that will allow for safe data transfer. Now, when you've safely xferred everything, you'll want to make sure you have OFIT capabilities on a sterile laptop. Using a CDBX compiler you can translate the data into PTRS files and then you'll need a second translator with a second laptop to recreate the DBSR files and produce a carbon copy of the laptop. Of course this is dangerous as the LPSF files can corrupt themselves, so you'll want to back everything up immediately. This is best done using both a SDRFT module encoder and a PRTRT module encoder. Lastly, you'll want to clean the data with a YPQRT program, I suggest one with DSRTI capabilites... Because we all know how finnicky those LSRTP scripts can be! LOL! I'll take my gold in the form of any extra RPT179 scripts please, sigh, alas my IRTAD data modules are so loaded with code and files that my poor RPT modules are starting to lag... Hmmm.... then again I could reprogram my BVQRS program and find a workaround with some old FRPTR files...
