BEST COD GAME SO FAR!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
CALL OF DUTY INFINITE WARFARE REVIEW.(Pros and Cons, Personal opinions and Useful Information about buying)TL:DR: Call Of Duty Infinite Warfare does not deserve all the hate it is getting, If you played it yourself you'd find it the one of the best damn games in the series.Pros:-Great Story-Game Mechanics are top notch-Weapons are awesome-Really well designed-Vehicle mechanics are better than most games-Gives kind of the star wars feeling-Fast paced action-Amazingly optimised-Awesome charactersCons:-It does take 76GB of space-First time startup takes a while to load, after that launch it doesn't need to load much anymore-Does freeze for a few seconds every now and again to refresh steam overlay. Easily fixable-Some weapons sound the same-Kind of short main storySINGLEPLAYER:Single player campaign has got to be one of the best I've played. Aside from Black Ops 2.The characters in the story are just plain badass and really awesome to play as, you play as Captain NIck Reyes, he was promoted to captain of the UNSA fleet after the recent Captain had been killed alongside the general due to an SDF invasion. The SDF forces are the main enemy in the game, they attacked your homeland and terrorised the planet. You have to evacuate from the planet using your mothership and continue your raid in outer space. You can ride various customizable JACKALS. Jackals are spaceships similar to star wars, they shoot missiles, rockets, flares and MACHINE GUNS that you can use in ship warfare in space which is EXTREMELY fast paced and all action fun. I shouldn't be spoiling too much else of the game, basically take down the enemy forces from the ground up, literally. MULTIPLAYER:Very, very fun! It is sort of hard to find a game since the multiplayer servers aren't as active as before. But when you join you have a massive variety of weapons to choose from and really awesome action gamemodes. Consisting of some of the classic modes like Deathmatch, gun game and  capture the flag. Even introducing EXTREMELY fun NEW gamemodes like gesture warfare which is funny and fun to play. Overall, the multiplayer in this game is a BIG upgrade from multiplayer in games from the other series. If people played more then maybe they'd see the brighter side of it. The AI isn't bad either, better than a lot of other games AI. I would highly recommend to try this out whilst playing, I can guarantee you'd have a lot of fun. WE JUST NEED MORE PLAYERS.ZOMBIES:Zombies... oh my lord it was amazing. This game gave the zombies mode a new shine of light. Never seen before in other games and one of the best improvements to the mode in the series. It introduced different MOVIE BASED situations, which were EXTREMELY FUN. Reminded me of the early days with Left 4 Dead 2. In the new zombies move you play as a gang of 4 people, almost sounds like scooby doo. And there are many zombie situations and maps to choose from including bonus DLC to buy and they ARE WORTH GETTING. Overall the zombies mode is an epic upgrade from the other games including STORY BASED appocalypses and characters which have different personalities and equipment. You'd enjoy this mode very much trust me. After playing the other versions in other games. You'd be freaking overwhelmed by how good they've made the mode in this game. The zombie weapons are very effective and useful, there is a big variety to choose from and all do sustainable damage. It is just undescribable of how good this game is and this gamemode in particular. You should really try this.OVERALL:Call of duty: Infinite warfare is almost one of the best games in the series, you should really try it despite the bad reviews. It is sooo amazing. There are a few buggy startups which are easy to work around once you start playing. This is game is just so amazing I don't even know the words for it. There are so many people that put their hard work into this, a lot of companies, devs, publishers, customers and the community. fuqin fun and adictive 8.9/10
I'm not gonna lie - this game is a lot better than everyone makes it out to be. While yes, it may be another future-set FPS, and yet another Call of Duty installment, this game does a lot right. First, Infinite Warfare refines the implementation of the movement mechanics introduced in Advanced Warfare and expanded in Black Ops III (wall-running, thruster jumps, etc). Compared to the previous year's installment, it definitely makes great strides in fixing the major problems involved - for example, Infinite Warfare provides a "Tactical Mode" in multiplayer, meaning that the updated movement mechanics are disabled - the map plays like it would in Black Ops II or any games before that. However, Tactical Mode doesn't need to restrict the playable map area or need to be played on only select maps - it works perfectly on all maps, as if to prove that it doesn't need the updated movement mechanics to be playable, unlike Black Ops III. Second, Infinite Warfare also introduces some very interesting concepts - among those being outer space-based gameplay. When I say that, I don't mean something like Mass Effect, where you fight aboard a spaceship. I mean combat that utilizes the low-gravity environment that outer space provides, with accurate simulations of what movement, gunfire, and physics would be like in outer space. This is something that is rarely seen in other FPSs, and definitely not in the "3D" manner that Infinite Warfare constitutes of. This is not to say that Infinite Warfare doesn't have its flaws - there are some features I don't agree with, the biggest of these being the implementation of pay-to-win mechanics - but it certainly does correct quite a few of the mistakes that the previous Call of Duty installments - especially Call of Duty: Black Ops III - have made.

The Single player was a blast to play through and there are many charcters that I had a connection with and got attached to. The multiplayer is another story however, but it is the same run of the mill Call of Duty style game play many of the fans fell in love with years ago, the game isn't really bad, at worse you can call it mediocore, but this game is worth the Single player and the Zombies expereince.

I’m not a multiplayer guy. But the campaign here is first rate. The level design is tight, focused, and well executed. The gameplay mechanics are clever and mix things up. The writing is on point for a military sci-fi story and actually matches typical novels in the genre. Good acting, good delivery, snappy pace.Are there problems? Sure. Is this one of the best FPS shooter campaigns in recent history? Yes. Given the number of good single player campaigns lately, it may raise eyebrows to see yet another held to that standard. But this delivers on the bombastic thrill ride you always hoped a sci-fi call of duty might be.It’s short, but it’s worth the price, especially if you like the trappings.
Not Interested in Multiplayer but thought the campaign was fun and took me a while to complete on Veteran difficulty. Great Challenge 8/10
TL:DR Why does the internet hate this game so much? There are actually a few different reasons:1. The main reason why this game got so much hate when the first trailer came out is because it was the third year in a row of science-fiction Call of Duty games. After Advanced Warfare, (2014,) and Black Ops III, (2015,) the fans of Call of Duty were aching for a return to the boots-on-the-ground style of warfare in either the modern era or in World War II, and with Infinity Ward's turn to release a Call of Duty game rolling around, most expected them to release Modern Warfare 4, Call of Duty: Ghosts 2, or some other form of modern or World War II war. Instead, we got slapped by Infinite Warfare, which not only continued the streak of science-fiction Call of Duty games, but took it a step further by taking things to space for the first time in the franchise. Hardcore fans from the Modern Warfare time didn't see this as a true Call of Duty game anymore, and the fans asking for a new Modern Warfare or a return to World War II felt like they were just given the finger. This is the main reason why the public outcry was so bad.2. Activition bundled Infinite Warfare with Call of Duty 4 Remastered as a cheap marketing technique, forcing players to buy this if they wanted the remaster of the first Modern Warfare. While it was Activition's decision and therefore their fault, Infinite Warfare itself picked up a good chunk of the hate from this.3. In recent years, most gamers have seemed to gravitate towards multiplayer games, such as Battlefield or Titanfall, which currently hold the titles as the giants of the FPS genre. With Battlefield's open combat plus drivable vehicles, and Titanfall providing parkour verticality in their gameplay as well as the ability to pilot Titans, Call of Duty stuck with its tried-and-true multiplayer formula of parking-lot-sized maps with a lot of corridor shooting, which let's face it, gets blown out of the water by the much bigger scales of combat put forth by the giants. People may have liked this type of multiplayer in the Modern Warfare era, but by the time Call of Duty: Ghosts rolled around in 2013, most multiplayer fans had already migrated to Battlefield 3 or Battlefield 4. This has resulted in an exponential trend of hate for the Call of Duty franchise, since it can't stand up to the giants in their multiplayer aspects, despite having good singleplayer. This is why the entire Call of Duty franchise is hated these days, actually. They just hate the multiplayer and don't care about the singleplayer campaigns.However, if you focus on singleplayer, this is actually an excellent game. It's got good characters, a fine story, and most of all, a memorable universe. There are also a few new features that singleplayer gamers will enjoy. Mainly, sidemissions. There are now optional story missions that can be skipped, but feel like full missions and provide perks and upgrades as an incentive to do them. Doing all of them will give the player multiplayer-style upgrades like Sleight of Hand and Quickdraw, increasing their power and allowing them to chew through enemies that much faster. There is also a loadout system in singleplayer where you can choose what weapons you take into battle, with a total of three slots, plus a recommended slot that can be configured for one mission. On top of that, Jackal missions (where you fly a fighter in space combat,) are a blast in my opinion, although I can understand if people don't like them.Overall, if you're a singleplayer gamer, or a Call of Duty fan, or a fan of science-fiction, or all of the above, then I highly recommend this one. Going off of the singleplayer, this is an excellent game that I've played through twice and enjoyed both times. You'll like it. And if you think the price is too high right now, wait a few months or maybe a year or two, and it'll go down.

story is good , and i said story
I initialy bought this partly for the campaign, and for that alone I've given it the 'thumbs up': it's one of the best campaigns I've played across  game, let alone for a CoD!Zombies is fun, as well, which was the other half of why I bought the game; each map has it's own quirks, fun places, and each of the 'guest stars' are well placed. Even the boss fights for the Easter Eggs aren't terribly hard (except maybe for Spaceland lol), and even on solo are completely doable.One thing that pleasently surprised me was how much I enjoyed the MP at the start, and have continued to do so through all it's faults (yes, cheats do show up) and unbalanced areas (Synaptic and VPR, looking at you!). However, over all, I'd have to say it's well put together, and that Infinity Ward have done a remarkable job in caring for it through the year's lifecycle, and continue to do so even after that has 'ended'...
NOTE: I haven't touched the Multiplayer at all. I tried the Zombies briefly and found it okay but with weapons that had the trademark 'weak' feel from the other Zombies modes.I thoroughly enjoyed the single-player of this game. The creators crafted a highly humanistic story that gave faces and names to the characters around you. They took a chance and added the 'Jackal' sequences to give you a taste of vector thrust space combat. The gravity and oxygen became consierations as you jump and grapnel from surface to surface, seeking better angles on your objectives and adversaries.If there was anything bad I can say about the campaign, it is how 'Bad' the members of the Settlement Defense Front (your main adversaries) are. There is no space left for shades of grey as you are pitted against an enemy who routinely goes for the most vicious plan of attack and whose stated goal is the complete destruction of Earth (because, reasons. But also because of the reasons from 'Red Faction'.)There are also one or two highly contrived story points, but overall it is written well enough to provide you with something to consider whe you're back on the bridge of your command vessel, browing the logs at the Captains terminal or starring at the 'Deck of 52' target board.Also, stay through the credits.

it's a ok game!.
Do note that this review is written in regards to the campaign only.Call of Duty Infinite Warfare is an example of Infinity Ward learning to apply the positive changes Treyarch added to the franchise with Black Ops, putting their best foot forward, and producing a genuinely good campaign as a result of it.The characters are likeable and well-written for a CoD story. The villains, though quite one-dimensional, fulfill the exact role Infinity Ward CoD villains should. People come to these games to feel like a hero, not to sympathize with Space!Nazis. The story is simple, not bad.The gameplay is very much restrained compared to the likes of Advanced Warfare and Black Ops 3, with only a very limited version of wall running and the double jump returning, and in non-intrusive ways at that. The Space Fighter missions are actually quite entertaining, if generally on the short side. There are actual stealth sections which do not overstay their welcome, and the ability to modify one's load-out with unlockable weapons and attachments at the start of missions greatly expands upon the campaign's replayability.Nick Rehes, the protagonist, has an actual narrative arc he goes through over the course of the campaign; and unlike the sociopaths of Ghosts, is a geniunely likeable character despite the well-intentioned mistakes he can and does make.Infinite Warfare is up there with Black Ops 2 in campaign quality, and despite what the masses say, is absolutely worth your time if you play this franchise for the campaign.Peace to the Fallen.

Have seen some comments saying graphics are bad? Not sure how, they must be running this game on a potato
I dont know why people are hating this game, this game is good from what i have played
I really don't understand why this game gets so much hate. I really don't.I'll give my review for zombies and multiplayer as I haven't completed the campaign yet.This is where the game really shines for me. I have over 25 days played on Black Ops 3 zombies thanks to the season pass maps and chronicles. So I'm quite a big zombies fan. I'm not gonna review the DLC maps, because it would take far too long for me to do so. All you need to know about them is that, IN MY OPINION, some of the maps are better than Treyarch maps. Especially Spaceland, Rave and Attack.Infinity Ward had some really good improvements over Treyarch zombies. Every single trap is unique in it's own way, all DLC-weapons were added to weapon loadouts and to every zombies map, none of the Fate and Fortune cards were OP as hell, the ranking system doesn't have prestiges but it has 999 levels, and the weapon variants from multiplayer keep the zombies-experience fresh and interesting.I also like how they changed a few game-mechanics inside of zombies. You don't really get stuck on zombies anymore, as you can just kinda squeeze through them, but the zombies hit faster and are overall just more aggressive. I also prefer the new double PaP mechanic over Treyarch's Alternate Ammo Types. In IW, the double PaP just makes the weapon a bit powerful and gives it more ammo, so it isn't stupidly broken like AAT was in Black Ops 3.Then the characters. I have an unpopular opinion on this matter, as I actually like these characters and the way they were handled. The characters have a different personality in each map, which I really enjoy. For example, Poindexter is a nerd in Spaceland, but in Shaolin, Poindexter pretty much screams "♥♥♥♥ you!" What I don't like about them, is the lack of real character development behind them. But I really don't mind that, as the characters are entertaining to play as.The soundtrack in zombies is, in my opinion, the biggest improvement from Treyarch zombies. Every map has a unique setlist fitting the theme of the map, and most of the songs are fantastic. It also gives you something to listen to while playing.Zombies in Spaceland is a fantastic on-disk map. It has so much replay-value it's unbelievable. You have all kinds of side quests that you can do, but they aren't mandatory to get to a high round or just do well in general. I went to round 30 on my very first playthrough without even knowing about the Weapons of Rock (granted I'm a pretty good zombies-player)I think the boss zombie (Brute) is one of my favourite bosses of all time in zombies. The fact that he has a ranged attack first and after you harm him enough, he starts to run at you is amazing. I don't think he's to difficult, nor do I think he's too easy.And the Clowns. Oh, the Clowns... I think they are a great substitute to the standard dogs we've had for the last 9 years. And I LOVE how they can almost all spawn at once. Dog rounds were always kind of on the boring side. Clown rounds after round 25 or so are hilarious if you don't shoot them as soon as they spawn. Especially with 3-4 players.The soundtrack in this map is my favourite out of all the maps in IW zombies. The map is set in the 80s, so the setlist consists of hits from the 80s. My personal favourites are Europe's The Final Countdown, and I Wanna  Rock by Twisted Sister. You can listen to all the songs featured in Spaceland on Spotify or Youtube.The zombies mode in this game is my absolute favourite, and I recommend everyone to give it a good chance. If you don't like CoD Multiplayer get the game for the zombies. I mean, why not? You can get the game for like 10€.As much as I hated Black Ops 3's multiplayer, I really like this one. Everyone's heard of other people saying that IW is just a Black Ops 3.5. Well, they aren't wrong. Although the game plays like Black Ops 3, I feel like IW did everything better. The combat rigs are a balanced version of the specialist system, high caliber + flinch isn't a problem, and the maps are better.This is something I complain about every single time I play this game. The weapon balance in this game is questionable. What's that? You thought the Brecci was OP/annoying? The Brecci was underpowered compared to the Reaver. I mean, a semi-auto shotgun that can kill in one shot? What the ♥♥♥♥ Infinity Ward?And don't even get me started on the ♥♥♥♥ing M.2187... "Let's add the pre-patch models from MW2!" Brilliant idea...On the good side, every gun in this game seems to be usable. There isn't a single gun that is just absolutely useless, which is a really good thing for people like me who like variety. And I really like the way they handled the DLC weapons in this game. You can earn each weapon with a specific challenge, or you can just buy the season pass and get all the weapons immediately.I don't really mind the variant system in this game, as you can get almost all the variants through salvage. Most of the variants are really well balanced, with a few exceptions, of course. But since everyone has the Reaver unlocked at level 1, It doesn't even matter that a variant is a little better than the base weapon...A really good thing I like about the supply drop system is that you can use the keys you earned from zombies in multiplayer, and vice versa. I already have most of the variants I wanted so I only open crates for zombies to get more fortune cards. I love the fact that I'm able to use my keys from multiplayer for the crates in zombies.The maps in IW are really good in my opinion. Gameplay is fast and smooth, and the maps have just the right amount of flanking routes. Campers are usually easy to kill with the Rigs like the FTL jump or the Active Camo, and the maps offer enough ways to flank the campers. The Multiplayer in IW can be extremely frustrating at times due to the weapon balance, but it's mostly a lot of fun. The movement system is fluid and cannot be abused like in Black Ops 3 due to being more limited.Zombies mode is fantastic and has a lot of replayability.Multiplayer is a polished version of Black Ops 3, with a questionable weapon balance.
Extremely good game despite what people say about it. I have gotten over 120 hours and im still entertained...

Awesome singleplayer story, action packed
Nobody gives a♥♥♥♥♥♥if you hate futuristic CoD games, especially not me. The theme alone doesn't make it bad, it's likely you are bad instead.This game is quite good (both single- and multiplayer modes) despite all the critics it's taking: lasers, robots, alien landscapes, a nice story... can't say I'm disappointed at all.Booster moves have returned, which are not something I fancy, but custom lobbies allow them to be disabled, which is a nice trade-off for me. The weapon selection for this game is maybe even better than Black Ops 3.So yeah, if you are into sci-fi games and/or you like fast-paced multiplayer action, this will work out well for you.______A couple points I feel like elaborating on:Infinite Warfare's trailer was reported as one of the most disliked videos on YouTube.Then the game eventually came out, and a whole lot of people took it upon themselves to review the game in an extremely negative way (that still happens, as far as I see). The main reason? The "futuristic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that ruined it all". Or the fact that "CoD games beyond modern times make absolutely no sense".But I am not one of those people, thank goodness.Infinite Warfare is certainly a bold challenge for developers. After all, they're not creating a story that puts you in the middle of an event that has really happened (WWII), a familiar setting nonetheless (Modern Warfare) or an invented one that still retains some plausibility and similarity to it (Advanced Warfare). You are creating a future setting which forces you to use some inventive, and I'm not talking about weapons alone. Science fiction presence is strong in this game, just as it is in any other sci-fi movie or game.The only complaint I would have about Infinite Warfare is the return of booster movements.Boosters limit quite a bit the array of viable weapons one can bring in a match, and the habit of creating maps where marksmen will find themselves at an inevitable disadvantage only reinforces that limit. Out of 3-4 players, one is likely to whip out a spam-friendly weapon (like the Reaver or the Type-2) and just Rambo-run through the map.One would say this system is better in that it discourages camping, but - alas - it's not that effective against them (runners constantly trip on camper traps anyways). I have been on both ends of run-and-spam tactics, so that gave me some much needed experience for my opinion.Sure, you can also open a custom lobby and disable booster movements. Not as effective as just plugging yourself into the public matchmaking, but if you are member of a group that loves the game but dislikes boosters, this is for you. There are also "tactical gamemodes", but they are scarcely populated (if ever) so I wouldn't count on them (unfortunately).And, as always, I would have loved an even bigger selection of weapons.______So, in the end...It pains me to see such a trend for negative reviews and I have the feeling it's not because the game is inherently that much trash. Rather, people hate it because it's not Modern Warfare or WWII. Which is like saying I hate WWII because it's not cyberpunk. Maybe I should thank them, because they only made me more curious to take it up, and I'm glad I did. Also, one of my favourite cyberpunk games is about to die for good and, although Infinite Warfare is no exact equivalent and/or replacement, it does an excellent job at giving me a good futuristic experience.It's not a thing that I see everyday: the versatility of CoD combat system (although a bit rewarding for rushers and a bit less for everyone else) and a great sci-fi setting. Infinite Warfare rewarded me with both. Add a good campaign with a captivating, desperate story and characters that you are going to love (and miss)... how could I hate it?I wish Infinity Ward made more games like this, but I'll have to manage with this one until they decide to give sci-fi a second try.Black Ops 3 was nice, but Infinite Warfare totally blew my mind.I'd rather stay in space than down there, taking stick grenades up my butt.
Yeah it sucks but its great game but should be called Infinite Warfare not Call Of Duty Inifinte warfare
Happy 1st anniversary my most beloved game! It has been such a long and interesting year for me with this game. Still to this day, I can't write a proper review for this game, because of how much I like it and how much love is built up inside me so that I can't even express it. I daily checked Charlie Intel for any COD 2016 news since New Year. When I first saw the reveal trailer for this game, I was like "oh pleease, another futuristic COD? Seriously? C'mon I was hoping for a modern one! But then again the leaked cover image looked nothing like one, that I saw on Charlie Intel." I saw the dislikes and got surprised, but by the time I saw the trailer the dislikes were barely 10K because how early I saw it since I was sent a notification and I instantly tapped on it, but the L/D ratio was very negative.Eventually I grew more and more addicted and interested in the game, impatiently waiting for the release. I also fought many people in the reveal trailer's comments section and various other social media, saying that IW's hate was unjust.  Then I followed up and counted down for the E3 showcase, and I absolutely loved it! And then IW finally got the pre-order function on Steam, so I used all the money I saved up for it. Throughout the summer 2016 I was so much bored and didn't know what to do, playing bo3 made me sweat from boredom and I grew extremely tired of it (even tho I got addicted into SOE Easter Egg hunting). Then Comic Con dropped, I even got more and more hyped and excited for the game, I definitely loved the Campaign footage, and the cast was just amazing.Then I decided to make a thread here on Infinite Warfare Steam Discussion Forums out of hype, which is entitled "This Game Is Going To Be Game Of The Year 2016!". You can find it here in the forums, it's currently the most commented on thread in this whole forums. I took my time endlessly arguing and fighting off many-many haters out there. In the end it was worth it, I successfully told them off that everyone's opnion should be respected and it was about time haters ceased bashing me for my opinion, calling me a cod kid and all sorts of stuff. It's archived now, but you still can read through if you have the time.Time passed, the zombies and multiplayer reveal trailers released, and I couldn't get even more hyped. There was a beta arc going on, but I couldn't play it as I am on PC. The only thing left for me to do was to just wait for the release.November 4th came, the game got released. It was so awesome, tried mutliplayer with my friends first, dope...; days later finished the campaign and I couldn't be more thrilled and exhilirated, the story was so epic and aura-giving. I also couldn't be more hestiant to shredding tears, it was so damn good, and I also liked the little easter egg at the end of the credits, gets me everytime.Then I spent the whole year playing this awesome game, without even realizing how fast time flew by.  So yeah, that pretty much sums it all up, I'm never gonna go back to past-set games, only modern and future (and in between). I'm gonna get the game on Chirstmas tho, at least I'm planning to, mostly because of the vast player count, which IW didn't get. Now I can't play the game anymore, Infinite Warfare is now deserted.The only thing that is left for me to do is wait, as I have started a mental campaign for the road to Infinite Warfare 2 and Infinite Warfare 3. Yes, I have high hopes for them, especially when they flirted about it and mentioned them during summer; it got my pump up so damn high.
Very nice game, worth it.
The game is just a very very good game!Yeah i got a problem but i rezolved it very quick.I would rate the game 8/10

Mp Sp meh ... ZM not so meh !
I don't know if this is a good game by COD fans standards, but it is - and I say this about the singleplayer campaign, as I don't play multiplayer - a very good sci-fi action game in general. It's actually a bit sad that it will probably be overlooked by potential players because of the Activision and "COD" in the title, because it's basically action version of the first Mass Effect in a way. You fly in, jump out on the ground, run around the map and shoot, use special powers, jump into cockpit again, do some space dogfight, hitch a ride on a dreadnought, destroy it from the inside by hacking robots to kill their own captain, jump out in the space, see a very nice cinematic story development, use galaxy map, chose some side missions, kill some dogfight aces, crash, recover, ... And all the while with Battlestar Galactica vibe (surprise attack by a terryifing enemy, bare remnants of the fleet defending, every victory is kind of a defeat and so on).It's a fun game with solid mechanics and an interesting story. If you're reading this in 2018/19 or later, and crave for a solid action game in space/orbit but also on the ground, feel free to check it out, don't mind that it says "COD" in the title if you're not into COD. It could have been called anything else too.
I have to recommend this game, but there are conditions as to why I do recommend it. Keep these in mind while I explain1: I got the game with the season pass on sale for around 50 Bucks2: I have played almost every COD since COD 2 (only haven't played Advanced War)3: I do not love COD as a franchise, the last one I preordered was MW2Campaign:The Story is really damn good. The plot is very interesting and holds it's own as a scifi thriller. Voice acting and cutscenes (while there are a few too many for my taste) are incredibly well done. All the big moments in the game feel absolutely amazing to play, and there are so many of them. It feels almost cinematic but you are actively playing in game so good on you COD devs. Holds up on it's own, not long enough for 60 bucks, but it won't let you down.Zombies: This is not like WaW zombies at all, and it's actually a pretty good thing. There is this....flavor....that this iteration of zombies has that I have not seen in anything. It's quirky, it's deep af in regards to gameplay/gun modding/easter eggs, and it just comes off as well designed and overall a unique twist on a mode that I absolutely love. The only negative I would say is that the final DLC "Beast from Beyond" map is a little plain and those stupid♥♥♥♥♥demon mutant dog things are not a good placeholder for regular zombies. Too fast and annoying.Multiplayer:Last and certainly least is multiplayer. For perspective, the last MP in COD that I strongly liked was BO2. There is this sort of skill gap between players in online, and you will quickly know you are on the wrong side. People fly about and slide shoot you to death and tbh slide shooting is hard af, but these people somehow consistently do it. There is an aggressive learning curve well above the Titanfall-esque style of gameplay this game has. I remember playing the campaign first and thinking, "♥♥♥♥, I hope this isn't how movement works in MP or I'm boned". Sure enough, I was right. The speed and movement is solid, but absolutely way too fast for me to even warrant ever aiming down the sights in MP. IDK maybe I'm too god damn old for COD (I'm only 25), but to get twitchy enough to play this version could possibly ruin my life medically I feel. Also the servers are dead as♥♥♥♥♥♥ so good luck not playing against the super good people as they occupy a majority of the remaining players.Overall2 outta 3 ain't badI would recommend this if you have a group of friends who love zombies and you're willing to give the campaign a shot, this may be one of the best COD's you'll ever play. Only recommendation is that you wait for a sale that includes the dlc, cause each zombies map is the bomb minus "Beast". Overall, I feel fine spending the $50 for the game+season pass.TL;DR+Campaign+Zombies-MultiplayerSpend $50 or less for game and all dlc, you'll be happy.
Anybody who thinks this is the same old stuff just "reskinned" obviously spent $60 to play multiplayer, and never touched singleplayer. Which is a shame, as the single player campaign on veteran was fun, and challenging!
Don't listen to people who say this game is confusing or bad!This game is actually awesome, it's an upgrade of Black Ops III.The campaign has got a storyline and the multiplayer is very good(many things to do).BUY IT!

I don't understand why this game receives soo much hate. Yes it has 'jetpacks', but jetpacks speed up the gameplay and make it interesting. When i went to play COD 4 remastered, it felt too slow and full of campers. I think Advanced Warfare left a bad taste in people's mouth then refused to play any COD Jetpack game again. I admit, AW was the worst COD of all time because the boost jumping and sliding was too rapid, but when Black Ops 3 came out, they got it right. - Then Infinite Warfare followed. Slightly faster than BO3, but the jetpacks are better on IW in my opinion.Where Infinite Warfare lacks compared to BO3 is the MP level layouts and Zombies. My BIGGEST problem with Infinite Warfare though = Lack of PC support. The same for any COD on PC, gets little to no support and you will occasionally find a hacker or 2. Because of this, the player base on PC is quite small and the only mode you can ever really get into to find a game is Team Deathmatch. Bought this for the campaign and it was worth it. The best Call of Duty campaign since Modern Warfare 2. There are things in this campaign that you haven't seen in any other game before. Fighting in Zero G is extremely rare by itself, but a stealth mission in an asteroid field where you infiltrate a destroyer class ship? That is f*cking cool. In this campaign I didn't even hate the characters, they aren't so unsympathetic a*holes like in most Call of Duty campaigns. The campaign also has a new structure and there are even some side missions, which are obviously not as exciting as the main missions, but still good enough to be worth your time. A little disappointing that you unlock the "Specialist" mode only after beating the game. In this mode you don't have regenerating health, but a classic health system. The dogfights in space are very spectacular, but also really simple and it's almost impossible to die. The story doesn't go nowhere and the motivations of the bad guy are so absurd and never explained, and the villain is probably the most boring one from all Call of Duty games. There are tons of setpiece moments and the levels are in locations you haven't seen before in other shooters, not at this production quality and variety. Lots of small little neat ideas, like shooting glass behind enemies which will vent those enemies out of the room, or a hacking device to hack enemy robots for a short duration and self destruct afterwards.
Bought it for the story, 5 bucks on Key-Store. I must say, it was totally worth it.The first few Missions are really chaotic and intense, but thats not a bad thing.Thats the first CoD i played, where you have main- and side missions. Well, you have 3 Main-Missions. And plenty side missions, which are just way too short and don't affect the story at all.You got an own Space-War-Fighter, the controls are great. Shooting enemy fighters feels satisfying.Gameplay is ... Well, CoD since CoD 4. Not much difference. The Jump-Boost and Wallrunning feels more fluent and.. better than in Bo3.There are less weapons than in older CoD's, but that didn't bother me. There are two types of weapons:    >Energy-Weapons, which shoots lazer-thingies and do better against robots.   >Bullet-Weapons, which are just normal weapons and of course better against human.The Story is simple: Kill all Mars-People, because they want to destroy the Earth. Yes, the main charakter (you) talks.I needed 9 Hours to complete the campaign at highest difficulty.Graphics are good, the cutscenes look amazing. Still, the cutscenes can be annoying. They replay after loading screen. So you watch the same Cutscene twice. I saw plenty bugs, most of them were just funny to watch. But those bugs didn't destroy the game.Perfomance is surprisingly good, ran at V-Sync 75FPS without drops, playing on RX 480 and i7 7700k.A few missions are annoying and unfair, especially at the difficulty i played, but i did it.If they didn't call it Call of Duty, it probably would not be that hated, as it is now.Don't buy for multi-player, it sucks and i had literally no fun.- I'm not even bad or so, it just doesn't feel good to play. Didn't try the Zombie-Mode yet, and i don't think i will.

very good campain and multyplayer but it requires a monster of a pc to run any where near good
I don't buy games for the mutliplayer content, rather I buy them for the single player content/story. This game has an excellent story and the gameplay is fun and engaging. I think all or most of the negative reviews are because of multiplayer content. It all depends on what you want in a game. If you want a story and good gameplay in a single player game this game will give you about 10 hours of fun (if you do all the side missions). The only negative is the space combat feels like a shooter on rails, but the visuals are very nice.
The campaign is amazing, especially compared to the previous installments. The characters & story are well-written, easy to follow and very immersive. It's rather short as usual but still a great "interactive movie". The space combat is simple but surprisingly enjoyable. The soundtrack fits the sci-fi theme perfectly.The zombie mode is great too. It borrows everything from the Black Ops series but adds a lot more too it. The base map, Zombies in Spaceland, is enjoyable both with friends and alone. Great for players who love easter eggs, but casual gamers will probably enjoy it as well.Multiplayer isn't great. Probably my least favourite CoD multiplayer so far and I've actively played everything since CoD 4. If you're looking for a good multiplayer shooter you're better off getting something like Black Ops 3. All the immersion from the campaign is completely absent in multiplayer. Generic maps, gunplay isn't great, lots of cheesy weapons & tactics and a large cheating problem. Playerbase isn't active.Don't be held back by DLC or micro-transactions. The Season Pass is only valuable if you like zombies, and you're actually able to get most weapons in multiplayer by just playing the game. I would personally recommend it on sale for the zombies & campaign modes. Multiplayer is not worth it. Hopefully WW2's MP will be better.
Played for campaign. Its okay but a bit repetitive.
I will say, short and sweet, this is the best running COD yet, and the graphics are great. Story is good, I dont like the shaky camera very much though, overall I would recommend for single player, got it at 23.00, worth it!

This game seems to catch a lot of flack.  I went in without a bias.  I'll say upfront, I didn't dislike the scifi setting, and thought it was well presented without being difficult to believe,Full disclosure, I don't play multiplayer games very often, and have not tried the multiplayer portion of this game.  However, I found the campaign to be engaging, challenging, and beautiful.  Voice acting was good, graphics were great, settings were interesting, and the story was predictable, but fun nonetheless.  The game crashed on me twice in my campaign playthrough, but the frequent autosave functionality meant I wasn't set back very far at all.I enjoyed this title quite a bit.   If you're interested in a 15ish hour campaign that takes you on a pretty wild, if typical, COD ride, this will scratch that itch.

In CoD:IW multiplayer i've encountered cheaters few times but it's not as bad as in modern warfare...Anyway, if you're looking for very fast shooter with wallrunning and jetpacks i'd recommend this game for you.There is few things i don't like in this game, which are "microtransactions" and a lot of modifications for weapons, which means that people who're playing the game for some time already have better weapons... This is the biggest issue for me, weapons in game should have the same statistics because people new to the game are not only unfamiliar to the game rules and environment but also they have to use guns that are worse than the ones used by experienced players.Other than that the game is quite fun. I wouldn't buy "season pass" unless you want to play in zombie mode a lot because on PC there is not many owners of these DLC's so you'd simply waste your money.

I havent tried the multi or zombies, but those have always been an afterthought to me compared to the campaigns, as a veteran and enthusiast of COD 1 and 2, where the campaigns were the highlight. This game does so many things right and the setting of space is utilized to its utmost potential. If you are looking for a good campaign after all these years, its finally here, that is the only area this review is touching.

This review is based purely on the SIngle-Player Campaign. First things first I'm going to say that I really enjoyed this campaign. Way more than I expected to actually. I've always like sci-fi so I guess I went in with a more open mind than most people but I get a really good vibe from the art direction, design work and characterisation. Fans of series like Battlestar Galactica will instantly see the similarities.The characters were mixed but two particularly stood out for me. Great interactions with meaningful story impacts.Ultimately though it's the ability to pick your mssions, choose your load-outs and mixing in Raptor (space craft) combat that makes this game shine for me. Being in space is really well done with the idea of being in a fully 3D environment with movement in all directions; again, if you've watched Battlestar Galactica then you'll feel like you're in a Viper.Moral of the story is don't go by popular opinion; if you don't mind a sci-fi setting and enjoy first-person shooters with a modicum of story then this game will serve you well. I got it for £10 so it was well worth the cash, what it's worth to you will depend on how much you enjoy single-player campaigns.

I don't understand the hate....I've played the game for over 45 hours and can actually say, this is a great Cod game with very little to not want. The canpaign is very, very good. I love that you can choose your missions and the space battles are actually good. I'd say the campaign is similar to Star Wars Battlefront II's (2005) Galactic Conquest.  I'm not sure how great the multiplayer is, but the zombies are really fun alone and with friends. I'd say the best zombies to date. There are some PC related probems. Even with my 1080Ti it still is gltichy at times with ranodm studderig. At times the face animation, and audio is off and I'm not sure why.  While  I'm glad there is some sort of 21:9 support, but it's not perfect with some menu items cut off. In game though 21:9 looks fine. Biggest other setting I'd like is a FPS cap that you can slide.
Pros:- Great campaign with a solid story and some fun side missions.- Gameplay is smooth and there is plenty of variation.- Movement system feels great and allows for varied movement through maps.- Zombies isn't as good as Tyrarchs but is still good fun.- MP is fun but very frenetic and it will take time to get use to the speed of.- Runs well and looks good.Cons:- 90fps mp cap.- Lootcrate system which you can pay real money for is essentially pay to win. :(- Small playerbase.- No server browser (please bring this back for all cod games).- Only populated mp mode is TDM.Also keep in mind that whilst it runs fine for me some people have reported performance issues (though none here with and i7 3770k, 8gb of ram and a 970). Recommend getting when on sale, the campaign alone is worth the price of admission then and the rest is essentially a bonus.
NOTE: IF YOU DO NOT LIKE CALL OF DUTY, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME PS: Also, I've only put 3 hours in at the time of this review, this is more of my first impressions of a casual player.Okay, this will be a short one.This game's campagian is one of the better campagins in the Call of Duty franchise. It gets a 7.9/10.Right, this game's multiplayer is defiently almost dead, its kind of like a person on their death bed taking their last gasps of air for another hour before they collapse and stay dead. I cannot find many games, practically in the Oceania region there are only people on Team Death Match and Free for All. Don't buy this game for the multiplayer, this gets a 5.5/10 from me.The zombies, I don't need to say much about it, it is your average COD zombies mode, defiently can't live up to the vibe and overall fun of COD BO3's zombie mode. 6/10.This game has run fine at 1080p at medium/high settings on my i7 7700HQ and GTX 1050 4GB, and I've not experienced any crashes in my play time but I do find there are lots of FPS drops to 10, it is really annoying whilst playing online matches and espically zombies.Overall, this game is not worth anything more than $20. In my casual opinon, pick this game up on sale if you can for $20 - $30.

I have mixed feeling about this COD.  I thought the story idea (both space and ground based) to have a lot of potential, but, like so many other COD titles, I just thought it was over too quickly and needed some expansion.The gameplay and mechanics are still top notch and I enjoyed playing it.  I'd say it is really worth it at 1/2 price.  An "OK" purchase at near or full price.FWIW, I don't think enough effort is put into the PC versions.  I watch online vids of console players and they are hitting everything they even get close to, while with my PC version, it is more difficult with a mouse and keyboard to get the fine aiming I often need for the "sniping/stealth" mode I prefer.  I wish they'd make the gameplay/mechanics closer between the console and PC versions.Anyway, recommended.PS. I have high game hours because I leave the game running in the background when not playing.  Also, I do NOT like multiplayer games, so this review is of the Campaign portion, only.

Campaign is good
This game is extremely underrated. Most people disliked it since the beginning for not being a boots on the ground game. But this game is filled with great and polished content.It still has its many problems, like the grinding (which has been there since the begining of multiplayer CoD), the matchmaking (it's quick, but it's hard to find a good lobby) and the season pass (which has also been in the last CoD games and will be i  CoD WWII). Most of the problems Infinite Warfare has are not because of the advanced movement system, but because of the Call of Duty formula. If you still like the Call of Duty formula, you should give it a try.

The first CoD game I've played since World at War and it's still (mostly) the same thing. What drew me to this one was the setting (sci fi vs modern world politics) and although the bad guys were a bit of a caricature as a single player I did enjoy the campaign for what it had to offer, i.e. the variety in missions with some casual dogfighting, zero gravity assault and your standard CoD shooting with the addition of jetpacks and custom weapons. The hero was a bit bland and boring and the bad guy from the Game of Thrones TV show failed to impress but all in all the gorgeous sceneries and comfortable shooting mechanics made up for that. One mission which focused on stealth was particularly enjoyable and if the entire campaign didn't take too long to complete the good thing is that it didn't overstay its welcome by artificially dragging things out (I hate when that happens in games). The zombie mode is also a nice addition but it's a bit limited when playing solo (I assume this mode must be a lot of fun with friends though).
Best COD ever, best DABS out there.
Best COD since MW/MW2. True courage for Activation to venture into SciFi and Space genre. The single player campaign is way better than BF1. Wish the graphics could be a little better and they could fix the virtual memory over commit problem. If you don't have virtual memory turned on you need at least 24GB of RAM to run it and most of them are committed but unused!
Great Campaign, Multiplayer and Zombie and IW is optimized, it run well on GTX 1050ti with 2k resolution. But there's not too much players are playing this game and that is so sad :(
WARNING: IF YOU GAME IS SLOW, CHANGE THE REFRESH RATE IN THE SETTINGS TO 59!!!!!This game has been bashed so much; and I do not get why.The story so far has been awesome; the space combat is fun and entertaining although messy, with more explosions than a michael bay movie.I did get the game only for single player, and I can say that it is totally worth it. The graphic is awesome; the various gadget used (like the hacking tool) are really useful and with a purpose; and having limited charges make you think a lot before use it. Being a fan of space games in general, can't find really anything too bad about this game, after playing few hours of the campaign.I wish the game was less "on rails", but this is COD; it has always been like this; so no complains here. If other games would have the same level of graphics and animations, but with the freedom to fly your own ship, I think they would be really on top.AI is decent; they move with you, and do a decent job shooting enemies, although at times they are just stuck, and no matter how close an enemy is, they won't take him down, until you do and move forward. Again, this has been in COD games for long time, so nothing new.Can't say anything about the zombie mode, nor the multiplayer because I do not care at all about that aspect, so if it is good or bad, I don't really know, and honestly, I am not even interested in trying it. The main reason for me to get the game was the single player campaign after all.The game need a very strong hardware; so if you do not have at least a GTX980, better to move on; otherwise I have been playing at 60FPS in 1080p without problem.IF you like single player campaigns, with awesome animations and cutscenes, and enjoy COD stories, this game won't disappoint.

• The zombies is really the only saving grace of IW, besides maybe the MW:remaster• All of the zombies maps are very good, on par with old-school zombies imo (black ops 1 / 2)• Zombies• The easter eggs are all very comprehensive and entertaining to do• The overarching "Super easter egg" for after completing all of the map easter eggs provides a lot more replayability• 91 fps lock no matter what you do• No MSAA anti-aliasing (you can super-sample your resolution but it's not really the same thing)• Multiplayer isn't very interesting and is a cash cow for cod points• IMO campaign wasn't as good as other cods, the non-linear campaign progression with side missions isn't a good fit for cod• The active playerbase is INCREDIBLY small in comparison to console (usually under 5k people)• There are some people who openly cheat in multiplayer, I've played about 30 hours of multiplayer and I have only found a couple, but it shows that it's possible

Multiplayer is blah but the single player campaign is actually really really good.  Charecters are well developed for the most part with motivations being pretty cut and dry.  The voice acting is great and dialogue feel like proper contemporary military jargin without any real technnobabble to confuse the situation.  More Starship troopers than Apocolypse now, it tells it's story without any real time to breath.  Which is how a pure action title should play.Theirs a little star fighter and weapon customization thrown in for fun but nothing to personal.  Has some great set pieces and uses them well over the course of the 8-10hr campaign (took me 10.5hrs to complete all missions).New optional missions mix up the early game but once you reach the halfway point in the main story, the optional missions become locked out.  Thankfully, the game lets you know before you reach that point (though i wish it had told me one mission sooner honestly).Graphics are killer and the game is really well optomized.This is actually my favorite COD single player campaign now.  I"ll probably play it agian in a few months which is more than i've ever done with a COD title before.

Hello! This is my first review, so sorry for how bad it is.Just before we start, I bought this game for £6.99 on , wouldn't do it for an indie game but Activision are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, so I why not and bought it. I highly recommend you do the same.I am a fan of the COD series, and unlike most, I quite like the jump-around-your-head type stuff. People never gave this game a chance in the first place, hence all the negative reviews. I am just going to get the only really bad thing (in my opinion) out of the way, and that is the supply drop system. I don't care if you say you can grind the game, if you buy supply drops, you are at a considerable advantage. You can earn them, but the rates for earning keys and salvage are stupid. Luckily, if you do spend a lot of money on supply drops, if you don't get the thing you want, you can just buy it using salvage gained from the supply drops. Also, there are weapon variants that are not available through supply drops, so get grinding!Now the good bits. I know there are bots in the online service floating around, but the Matchmaking service is genuinely brilliant. Considering that there are only 1500 people in the game, 10 seconds as the longest time to get into a match is amazing. The feeling when you get a kill is amazing and very satisfying. The campaign is one of the best campaigns in a COD game, ever. I genuinely like the campaign as much as the one from Modern Warfare, and no other COD game has ever come that close in my opinion. The air combat is brilliant and frenetic, especially on high difficulty. The zero-gravity combat is really good as well. There are a few scenes where characters die, and I genuinely felt sad when it happened.Moving on to Zombies. It is good. The feeling of killing a fairly difficult boss is very satisfying, and there is no BO3-like usable items that give you an insane edge. I've never felt like I needed a Fate & Fortune card. I have not played them, but I have been told that the other zombies maps aren't great (DLC4 Excluded, it hasn't come out yet). Look further into it if buying Season Pass/Map Packs for Zombies.Overall, I genuinely feel like this is a great game. Shame about the Supply Drops though.
Bardzo mała ilość graczy ale gra sama w sobie bardzo fajna :D
I was looking for a recent, cheap casual shooter and thought: "Why not try COD Infinite Warfare", so I bought it for dirt cheap in another reseller and gave it a try. I have not played COD since MW3 and after 2 hours of playing IW in story mode I can say that im very happy with it. The graphics are amazing, the sounds are realistic, the voice acting and lip sync is on point. The gameplay is the usual COD gameplay and since it's in space, the weapons are high tech and there's thrusters on your suit so you can hover, wall ride and double jump, these mechanics gave the game a higher and more dynamic feel. I don't get why people hate this COD so much, I understand that for someone who bought COD every year it might have felt like more of the same but is it a bad, broken and unplayable game that deserves such low reviews? There are far worse games that do not deserve positive ratings such as those JRPG's that look all the same, made in RPGMaker just for a quick cash in from the Otakus that drool over drawn females or the games that exist just so people can farm cards and make money out of the Steam market. I look at COD IW as a Sci-Fi Casual Action Shooter and it does an amazing job at that. You play as a Lt. in the military from Earth which is at war with the army from Mars (now colonized). It's rebel leader wants to conquer the rest of the solar system because Mars had been neglected and only served to gather materials to bring back to Earth (this reminds me a lot of when the African colonies start to revolt against the empires that owned them). I'm having tons of fun playing IW. I did not buy it for it's online gameplay so I can't say anything about that but if you're looking for a casual shooter that has a good sci-fi feel and a good story then this is your go-to. Just dont buy it on steam for it's full price since you can get it for $15 or lower in other resellers.*incoming thumbs down*Edit: Forgot to mention, you can select the missions you want to do in the available planets from the Solar System and you have a lot of gameplay time piloting and fighting space ships in Star Wars like battles.

The bandwagon hate train is strong with this one. Can't lie, I was on the bandwagon myself too at one point. But I am an avid fan of CoD series since the original, so I have to get every one of them, no matter the reviews.And to my big surprise, the game was not a horrid as everyone would have you believe. The most positive thing I can say about the game multiplayer wise is that gun balance is done quite well in terms of CoD series. There's not particularly any clearly broken weapons, like in previous CoD's so weapon balance, while not perfect, definitely great. It's a pretty standard MP experience I do not think I have to go into detail. One of my gripes is the jetpack/wall run system is busted and lame in MP compared to Advanced Warfare. A lot of people just hovering in air spraying, here and there, otherwise its not that bad.I'd rate this CoD 8/10

First off, I don't really like the multiplayer for this game.Now then, the singleplayer campaign is probably the best part of COD:IW, probably one of the best and most dynamic storylines since COD 4.Now then, the multiplayer.Multiplayer feels somewhat class based, while still being that of COD, however most people don't really like the fact you can hover in the air, however there is a gamemode that is made to feel like old COD.Graphics: Definitely good looking, especially with the level design.Would I reccomend it? If you like futuristic sci fi storylines that feel immersive, then yes.If you are looking for an online multiplayer, this probably isn't the best place, go look elsewhere.
First, I went into this game with the negitive reviews in mind and also the positive ones as well.  So I looked at both point of views on this game.  I do not have the Season pass as there is no content for one to justify the money.Pros:GraphicsStoryacting/voice oversDifferent arena (Space)Neat weapons Cons:To short, would have loved more fighter time and even capital ship fightingSome custimization but not as much as there should be in game.Okay so my lists are small, but I do not play CoD for MP as I hate how many hackers there are in most of these games today, so i do not even bother anymore.  I actually enjoyed the game I liked the new arena of Space and bording ships etc...The only problem I had/have with this game is how short it is, The time I have as of this review is 34.8 hours and that is all side quests and main story done.  I don't care that much about steam achievements as they are like getting that "Participation Trophy" for sports.  If I get them great but I do not look for them nor do I really care that much.  I do have few but again, not my bag.I look at a game as did I have fun playing it?  Was it worth the money I spent on it to play Vs my time spent in game?  If both are answered in the yes, then I will recommend it, if one is not then I may still recommend it or not depending on how bad or game breaking it was.  I did not encounter any bugs of note, and I have an older machine with a decent card and ram.  (Hoping Santa will bring me a new gaming rig)So, final verdict is a solid yes and I plan on replaying it on the hardest level.  If I encounter something during that run I will update my review and note any changes.

I did wrote a review to this game relating unsolvable bugs. And I know quite well, that some people still have this problem.Some people might also give this game a bad review, because it's not a good Call of Duty game because of "that space ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t ain't what we wanted" but I thought "Well, it's an AAA Game developer. It might be a bad CoD but not a bad game. MAYBE."And this maybe turned out to be the truth. You know, I played all of the CoD titles from Call of Duty 1 over Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare until now. After MW2 - which was approximately around the time, many veterans of this franchise left and played other games like World of Warcraft, Dungeons & Dragons, League of Legends, DotA 2 and the list goes on and on and on.Now what I wanna say is - not everything back then was better, after playing the campaign I seriously had tears in my eyes, seeing the credits made me thought first "Holy hell, please don't be like that asslong credits in Black Ops 3!" but you could also fast forward, then I saw this long evaluate "Thank you" at the end of the credits from Infinity Ward, which made me realize again that those peepz aren't just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who wanted to make money as much as possible (though through all that extra♥♥♥♥♥♥you can buy you might can think so) but actually care for story and gameplay.The story was amazing, you had side missions, main missions, a good mix between vehicles and infantry (jeez this felt like the first time in CoD where vehicles actually had some importance). Also it wasn't anything like I played before, I mean sure some mechanics from earlier titles are in it but I mean the basic concept of missions, actually leading people to battle in this unique CoD style was a totally new experience for me as a veteran of this franchise.Okay, lemme evaluate the Multiplayer for you, first off - it's like the jungle there, eat or get eaten.Or kill or get killed, I mean sure, the first 20-30 levels I got beaten, sliced up, shot, frozen, electrified, burnt, sometimes everything at once. Sometimes I could just spawn and go for 3 seconds around and get shot instantly but after all, this is part of getting good. Get beaten to beat if you know what I mean. You must of course learn and adapt but that'll come with time.Now I'm what? lvl 40? And I actually have fun playing the Multiplayer. Tho the Skill requirement isn't as high as in Battlefield or in ArmA (whereas in BF I can still use some tactics from CoD to 0wn) but it's the fun that matters, right? However, the new mission team system is genius. Love it. Like Zombies. Oh my gosh Zombies.They want loads of hugs. And where I actually like to hug my girlfriend (if I had one) she might aswell want to shoot me (If I had one). The new Zombie mode is like the previous♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥killion ones (for me at least. Never really cared much about zombie mode) except that now you have cards instead of gummyballs and one thing that is probably the most important thing on earth.Mancrush of probably 90% of the peepz out there. Yes, he's not only the DJ in the Zombiemode, he's a playable character and also can helpo you out as an NPC reinforcement player.So yes, definitely, might be not the kind of Call of Duty everybody has in mind

Alright, so here's my thoughts on Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare's main campaign:I've played through most of the games of this IP. And I never really liked them much to be honest.Not gameplay-wise. Because of their totally idiotic enemy AI design mostly. To be quite fair, to create an enemy AI in these kinds of games are pretty hard to do, especially when you are supposed to storm the enemy, without making them too easy or too hard or just boring. Unfortunately, Infinite Ware is no different than the other CoD games in this regard. It's enemies work pretty much like the others. It's gameplay works pretty much just like the others. Like Modern Warfare or Black ops, take your pick.However, I noticed something really interesting once I completed the game I unlocked a new difficulty.This difficulty is how I think the game is really meant to be played.Instead of regular regenerative health, like all the other Call of Duty games you now have to manage your health and lifesupport.You get replacementparts for your suit and stimpacks along your route through the campaign.You will have to manage individual bodyparts, like if you take a shot to the leg, you won't be able to use ADS while moving. Nor sprinting. If you take a shot to the arm you won't be able to use ADS at all. (Aim Down Sight)It's called "Specialist"No health regeneration. Healing from Nano Shots only.Helmets take permanent damage and need to be replaced.Nano Shots and helmets take up equipment slots.Movement impacted by receiving leg shots.Aim down sights and equipment use affected by receiving arm shots.Enemies can shoot weapons out of your hands. Etc.The problem with this, is exactly the same as I  mentioned before: The enemy AI. They are far to good att hitting what they aim at, that is... probably you for the most part. They don't seem to care too much about your teammates, they mainly aim for you. And they will hit you. 99.9% of the time. If they made their aim a bit more... realistic, and guns a bit less accurate maybe... This game would have easily been game of the year material.Unfortunately, they didn't make any deviations to the Enemy AI or much how ballistics works. (Except that it will take about three or four shots to the head to kill an enemy... What's up with that really? I don't get it.^Of course, you can't take that ammount of damage or you will die. Unless you play regular. Where you can sustain an interesting ammount of damage and still keep going. A second or two in cover and you will be back to full health like usual.However, the campaign design in Infinite Warfare differs GREATLY from the other games in this IP.As Captin Reyes, you will have more or less full command of the warship Retribution.You can't fly it yourself of course, but you can choose some of it's missions!In other words there are main missions, and optional missions, and you can choose in wich order you want to execute them. Just like Black Ops, you can manage your equipment, from guns, mods and your "Skelter"Wich is you figter jet. Fully space capable with hyperspace abilities.There are special missions designed specifically for this fighter, so you will have the ability to take it out on raids, dogfights and everything and I totally LOVE this addition to the game. I find theese missions really enjoyable because they make this game a lot more than your regular Call of Duty military shooter.You're not a marine. You're not Army. Not Air Force. You are part of the Earth Navy.There is no "America" really anymore. It's just earth. Against, primarily Martian colonies that decided they need to take control of the Earth instead of just being used. (The Expanse? Anyone?)The Story writing in this game, is easily the best I've seen in any Call of Duty game!The campagin is easily the most enjoyable experience I've had in any one of them.Black Ops.. three? gave you the ability to manage your eqipment through your base of operations.Infinite Warfare leaves you in charge of the Retribution, a capital ship in the Earth Navy.So not that much have changed there.The weapons however, despite at first being very similar to the Black Ops experience, is overhauled and gives you a much more distinct feel for them. They feel individual and you will pretty fast learn wich ones you like more than the others.There's one in specific I really like, a submachine gun that doubles as a shotgun. Unlike the other CoD games, not all your weapons are ballistic anymore. As you will face combat in space and zero-g, some of the guns are energy-based.(However, I noted that ballistic weapons works just fine in space as well so this addition was a bit curious...)Energy weapons does not work better on bots either, but the guns power/damage output decides what kind of damage they do in general. They should have made that addition, energy based weapons should be better on bots, while ballistic weapons should be more efficient on people. I AM pretty glad they didn't addition energyshields to the mix though.The game would have felt more like Halo if they did, instead, without them, the game feels more like something else.Like it's something own.Gunplay in Infinte Warfare is pretty much the same as Black Ops 3 in general.Same thing about mods management and equipment slots.But they have somehow a lot more personality to them.I like what they did here. I really do.Pity about the AI, that drags the score down.And... yeah, bots... feels really lame.Especially since one of them is actually on your team and he is unnervingly human.Voice and emotions, the whole shabang. E3N or, Ethan. ^^I give the campaign a 8 of 10.It looks really good, it's writing is really, really good!But plays out more or less the same as the other call of duty games. Sure, they wanted to make a Call of Duty... They could have made something different if they wanted.(And I thing they secretly really did!) But Activision decides I guess....The game could easily have been amazing, had Infinity Ward gotten free reins with the IP.Something entirelly different. Not new, it reminds a lot about what Unreal 2 - The Awakening was trying to be.Infinite Warfare COULD have been that!Gung Ho captain with a capital ship going corsair.Or maintaining the law... It could have been another Mass Effect had they wanted it to.But better. As good as the game really is, I can't help but see a lot of wasted potential!If you expect a Call of Duty experience you won't be disappointed.More likely strangely suprised with what they have accomplished.So, 8 out of 10 for a Call of Duty singleplayer experience is not a bad score.I recommend playing it!As for the multiplayer.... I never liked CoD's MP mode much.Maps too small, guns too boring, gameplay too... I don't know.I didn't try Infinite Warfares multiplayer, nor the Zombie mode.But expect more of the same. Same weapons as the Black Ops 3 experience more or less.I STRONGY recommend a computer that runs the game at 100fps or more and a G-Sync of FreeSync monitor(Depending on your graphics card)It's a totally different experience than playing it i 60Hz V-Sync.(Those that have tried this, knows what I'm talking about)And put that xbox controller of yours aside, use the mouse.(I usually PREFER playing with a controller, but not with these games)

The massive like/dislike ratio on the reveal trailer, the futuristic setting and all, but since I have all the games in the series will I buy every one that comes out, since it's one of my favorite series. it is actullaly ok
Campaign: To all those people who think this game is bad. It really isn't. Still better than Ghosts. But most people have barely any hours on it and claim it is the worst game ever. Well it isn't. The campaign is probably one of the best I have played in all of Call of Duty so far. It makes you really care for the characters when they die because of how you are always with them and you grow around them by them helping you. This game has pretty sad ending to it when you hear their tapes to be played at death. And the missions in this game are really fun out in space because you can do all kinds of stuff with the movements and watch a lot of the neat stealth takedowns in this game.Multiplayer: The multiplayer isn't that bad when you start getting used to it. Don't go for the Dominion achievement it is bugged. But if you want to get better then just level up and you might have some fun mowing through some people. The only thing you will pay for is DLC everything else is optional but if you want to have some fun you might spend some money on it to get better varients. But I have not spent much more than $10 on cod points and I have gotten a lot for just that amount because of how you can earn keys in Zombies too. So you can kill everyone if you play zombies a lot and earn the varients from playing that.Zombies: Probably my favorite part about this game. When I heard them making zombies I didn't think they would be at all good. But when you realize it the storyline is much more in-depth than you may have though. As I mentioned before you do get keys in this mode. So if you don't want to spend money on this game for Zombie Crates you don't have to. Because of them adding bounties you can get 30 keys a single bounty which might be somewhat difficult. But other than that it is really fun to play all the maps that link in together with the Soul Key. Willard Wyler doesn't want you to get these so then your four main characters known as Sally, Pointerdexter, AJ and Andre. They pick up the Soul Key and go on to the next map. This is telling you that all the maps are connected. And all the mini easter eggs within this mode. Such as the film reel with Point of Contact on it. (Call of Duty: Ghosts first map) which tells you Willard Wyler directed this. And this really adds the detail to the game. And I love how after beating each easter egg you get to play as the Celeb in that map such as David Hasselhoff, Kevin Smith, Pam Grier and Elvira so far. Which makes doing the easter eggs so much more worth it.And this is why I really like Infinite Warfare I hope this helps you decide if you want to buy this. If you don't like it remember you can refund if you have under 3 hours and not bought later than 2 weeks so try it and see if you like it. You might enjoy this game!
