First of all, I only played the campaign.  I don't do multiplayer shooters anymore, I just don't have the spare cycles to suffer cheaters, delinquents, and map memorizers anymore.SummaryThe campaign was OK.  The game is plagued by too many "howevers" as you will see below.  If you're like me and only want the story campaign, then it's worth a go if $20 or less.  I got it on sale for $29, which I felt was slightly high for what I played.  My hours are off because I accidentally left it running all night one night.What I liked:I liked the fact that I could choose side missions from a mission map what I wanted to do, however, you are able to do almost all the side missions before doing the first campaign mission after becoming captain of your Space Carrier.  This almost completely caused a continuity disconnect with the story campaign.I liked the most wanted board and chose missions to hunt down these NPCs, however, the last 5 or 6 you never get to see the cards completed for reasons I can't get into for spolier reasons.I liked that the gear was 3D printed and you had to scan weapons you found to add them to your ship's database..however, it was obnoxious that the weapons you haven't scanned yet show up in the database and some of them you don't even encounter until you reach the point where you won't enter the armory again.I liked that there was customization of the weapon attachment and scopes, however, the limitations should be based on position of the attachment on the weapon, not the number of attachment slots in the UI.I liked that there was transition from FPS to Space Fighter and back again in the same mission, however, it was all scripted so there was always the "guard rail" feeling, though I think this is an issue present in the entire franchise.  You never really get to roam your entire ship though there is no reason in this engine that you couldn't aside from the developer's willingness to do so.  I know its not Star Citizen, but some freedom would be nice.Ethan was just great, no however here.What I just couldn't stand:The target locking pursuit thingy...nothing like it running you into enemy capital ships or asteroids all the time.Missiles...fairly pointless as the gun upgrades you get are pretty much all you need.The story gets a little too ham fisted with the "burden of command".The captain's computer is pretty much worthless.
Great Game
Not a huge fan of the COD series mp, I think the run and gun in a shoebox concept is absolute garbage and it's a shame so many mp games have moved in that direction, but I have taken the time to beat the sp capaigns of each series entry as sales pop up on steam. And while I don't think any of the recent entries have been particularly noteworthy; this game included, I am inclinded to leave a favorable review in light of the excessively negative press. And for the most part, the game is actually decently done. Still a dated engine, but the level design isn't bad. There is definitely a sense of scale. Dialogue is well written for the most part. And the conversation flows and doesn't seem forced. Besides one awkward moment where people were laughing at one of Ethan's joke that wasn't particularly funny. Would I go out of my way to recommend Infinite Warfare to my friends? No, absolutely not. In some sense, the outrage is justified. The franchise is done to death. It needs fresh life. This game is certainly not worth full price. I can appreciate the scale of new games and the manpower required, but games are absolutely not worth $80. I still believe profit margins should be reduced. And it's absolutely outrageous that Activision thinks they can charge $50 for COD4 remastered and force you to buy Infinite Warfare to purchase it. Thankfully that was later rectified. But I hear they're charging more for DLC that was included free in the original title. Hopefully that was also addressed. I don't care if it's a remaster, you can't charge full price for a decade old game. Halo gave you 4 games for the price of 1 COD game. The remaster is worth $30 at most and I'm leaning more towards $20.My review will be mainly focused on the single player campaign of Infinite Warfare. As a fan of Ace Combat and HAWX, the arcade style space combat was a welcome addition. It certainly filled the void where Starwars Battlefront failed *cough* And with the exception of a few scripted events and level sequences, it was not a rail shooter. It was definitely satisfying to see the transition from ground to orbit to docking or forced entry on hostile ships, followed by descending into the bay and moving about the ship. Definitely gave a sense of scale. Especially with the ftl/slipspace travel. Watching the jump from the bridge. The hanger did seem a bit bare though. Given the amount of armor you later see. And knowing there's more than 2 gunships. But all the detail, did add to the immursion. Story delivery-wise, the campaign seemed to jump around too much, with the side missions giving too much freedom to play them in any order. One second you get this sense or urgency of an impending invasion, the next you can choose to protect a salvage run rather than defend your home planet.... That feels unnatural and runs the immersion. On earth, I defintiely got a 2142 vibe every time I saw a Titan.. err Destoryer in low orbit. Gameplay mechanics like avoiding the burning sun, or popping a door slowly or kicking it in were thoughtful. Turning robots on humans seems a bit repetitive. New material please. The boosters..... those need to go. I still keep my boots firmly planted on the ground despite the boosters. It will always feel forced and ridiculous performing wall runs. And boosts should be saved solely for landing high jumps with minimal impact. That's minor, and I can appreciate the vaulting system in place.On the other hand, some things did seriously irritate me... the entire concept of the SDF hating freedom and hating the people of earth seems a bit ridiculous. The quotes when you die especially.. It's not believeable. Most wars, however ridiculous, e.g. religion, are fought by people who fight and believe in something... people tend to be rational, even if misguided. The idea that a group would hate freedom is implausible.. The SDF are fighting for independence, they want FREEDOM. Quotes saying they hate freedom are a bit ridiculous. The delivery was off. And I really don't see someone so young being an admiral and leading such a large movement. Especially someone with such lack of emotional discipline. And on that subject, WHY THE F*** IS A LIEUTENANT NOW A COMMANDER. I understand 95% of the fleet was wiped out, but before then the lieutenant and admiral were in contact. An admitral wouldn't even acknowldege a lieutenant in the military. A kid straight out of academy or university would be granted the rank of lieutenant.. And why was a private first class leading the marines after the Sgt. died?! Am I missing something.. a PFC is the lowest rank of all. Anyone flying in the airforce/navy would likely be a major or a colonel. The choice of navy did seem more fitting than air force, given the concept of battleships. Back to the enemy forces, the entire SDF seemed void of personality. And there was a total lack of effort on the voice department. Unless I'm fighting the 501st again. The same voice over and over.. really destracted from the experience. AND FOR THE LOVE OF GOD WHAT THE F*** IS WRONG WITH THE CUTSCENES. Cutscenes were horrifically laggy... I have a 1080ti, 6700k, 16GB DDR4, 1TB SSD, etc. THis should not be happening in a released product, nevermind one that's been out on the market for over a year. You can't expect me to turn down cache or shadows with $6000 of the best hardware on the market. Back to characters, The UNSA characters are more memorable than the SDF, but I'll still forget them, just not Ethan <3 and as usual everyone dies and you feel horrible at the end. gg COD. At least the developers suceeded at delivering a powerful ending. It's an interesting story, but at this point I feel the entire franchise is stale, living off of bad multi-player. The campaigns are far too short. There isn't enough content for the price being asked. Don't buy this game unless you want a quick thrill and have cash to burn. Otherwise, go buy playerunknown's battleground, killing floor 2, payday 2. There's plenty of other franchies with more to offer. This is not a game where you're going to get $1/hr out of. More like $10/hr.
This was surprisingly great.Very fun campaign with lots of pretty set peices to shoot things in front of.That's all I ask from one of these campaigns.All those impossible to follow plotlines with interchagable army-men characters are thankfully absent from this entry.I wouldn't say the story was good, but it wasn't as actively annoying as most COD games which distract from the action.Multiplayer was pretty fun, default COD stuff.

This game is far better than I had expected. I was not a fan of Advanced Warfare when it was released a couple of years ago and my biggest complaint was all the jumping and jet-packing around. I figured Infinite Warfare would be the same, but to my surprise, it's much better. The controls seem to be improved and the all the jumping around doesn't seem all that annoying. It actually fits this game better than it did with Advanced Warfare in my opinion. I like the Quartermaster idea, too.  Overall, this game has me hooked and I can appreciate all the bonus content that you can earn throughout your battles.
The game singleplayer/campaign mode has a detailed storyline, I personally enjoyed it far more than Black Ops III's singleplayer. As for multiplayer, not as good as BO3, but still enjoyable. Lots of weapons to choose from depending on playstyle, but I find myself being killed one too many times by the combat rigs and such. Zombie mode is very fun, and I could play it for hours on end. Zombies in Spaceland is my favorite out of all of the Infinite Warfare Zombies maps. Black Ops III's Zombies was too storyline based, where IW's version just has 4 characters teleporting in time to different locations, (kinda) similar to BO3's zombie mode. Overall, I would not recommend this game to people who won't want to spend 59.99 on a game they may not even enjoy. If you have 60 bucks laying around, go for it, its a solid game although a lot of cheaters in multiplayer mode.

People putting down Call of Duty is exactly what other game companies want you to do, hell I make games so I'd want you to do the same. But I also believe in self respect, so I'm not gunna lie to myself and trash talk this game, cause its good, and here is why.If you used to be a console player its most likely you use a controller, well this games controls are so silky smooth unlike most other games, especially PC exclusives they either have no game pad support, or looking around or walking just feels horrible. Not to mention it has rumble pad support so when you are mowing people down it just feels f-ing great. I watched a GDC talk from the guy who did the networking for call of duty, cant remember if it was this one, but what I can tell you is the video talked about how much time they spent making the networking smooth, just like the controls. And after playing I can definitly confirm that the online is seamless with no delays between anything.Don't be a sheep.

*** Review for SINGLE PLAYER game ***I liked this game!  The story, characters, and gameplay.  Loved "Ethan" (E3N) especially.It held appeal because of the game's incorporation of "values".  For instance, the marines(?) commander's viewpoint toward Ethan changing over time.  The hatred for the people of Earth on the part of the Martian humans, and their collective, communal drive toward expansion and dominance via war ... it being their societal ethic.  Made me happy to bring 'em crashing to ground!  :DThe "Klingon in me" was glad to see sacrifical deaths of heroes.  Nothing new in that with CoD instalments, heroes going down in battle.  But   These sorts of things, for me, make satisfying endings to stories.I found it both an interesting and a good addition to the CoD franchise to have the side missions to different parts of the solar system.  Missions to assault fleets or facilities using space fighter-craft or as ground assaults.  They added more content to the single-player experience.  I played them all through the first time.  However, they are optional ... at least in subsequent plays through.  I don't know if the "chance of mission success" figure for each side-mission had any bearing upon the difficulty of the main game's ending.  When I had my second play-through, I don't think I did any side missions.The game controls seemed typical and thus natural and easy.  The character motion/animation was (imo) good.  Two-stage negotiation of obstacles such as walls with NPCs is probably fairly standard, I guess, being a bit of a cut-scene thing.  ** There's a game called "Warface", a free-to-play multiplayer FPS that uses two players to perform such two-stage manoevers!  First to boost one up, the second to pull the booster up.  Kudos to the Warface devs!  :D **There was a satisfying variety of environments.  Most notable for me was probably the darkness caused by dust/smoke during one stage of the attack on Earth.Heaps of weaps to pick up.  Customise your loadout for each mission if you want.*** The bad ... ***There was crashing ... and it wasn't just a few times.  I think it was mainly an issue with my PC setup though.  *Very* unimpressed with my GFX card.  It's been crashing for everything.  Most play was during the summer (southern hemisphere), so cooling issues really came into play.  Aimed some fans into my open PC case.  That *largely* resolved the issues.  I used a Gigabyte R390.  It was capable of displaying full HD but seemed unstable.  However, I had removed the OC Guru s/w and I think the result was that the fans weren't operating optimally because the OS didn't know the metrics.  My mistake.*** Summation ***I liked it.  Only played it through twice though.  This is typical for me on SP FPS's because, unlike action-RPGs (FPRPGs/RPS), they don't have the same depth of character customisation that encourages "a different approach".

Honestly its better than I expected. Movement feels smooth. I personally never had a problem with jet packs or aerial gun fights in COD or any other franchise, so Im a fan of what theyve done here. Guns kill a bit too quickly though. Sometimes I feel like I should put some more bullets into enemies to kill them. Im not interested in zombies or single player campaign, so I wont comment on that. Never had much connectivity issues, other then lag here and there (but nothing game breaking). I found one hacker though, hopefully its not something reoccurring. Overall, pretty good game. Its a shame I didnt get it before.

Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare is not a bad game, say what you want about it. Yes, the PC port of the game isn't that great, when the round starts you'll have some lag, but the game feels different compared to it's futuristic predecessors. It might be    because of the fact that the Supply Drops are different (If you get a Weapon Variant you'll get the weapon itself). Other than that, I really enjoyed playing this game even though it is a futuristic Call of Duty.

This game is set many decades before the main events of Halo, actually being set during the Insurrection Era where the UNSC executed Operation TREBUCHET to destroy the Insurrection threat once and for all. I loved how well 343 Industries managed to execute a game where you play as a marine captain with his squad to take on suicide missions to end the Insurrection threat.Of course, there aren't any Covenant or Spartans in this game since this is set before that time but ODSTs and Marines are as epic in this amazing new take on the Halo franchise.

*MULTIPLAYER REVIEW ONLY*                    I dont think this game deserves all the hate it is getting, with a good system I am getting high framerates with minimal stuttering that doesnt make the game any less enjoyable, for 30 bucks on sale or to play during a free weekend its actually a pretty fun game, in short bursts its a nice casual fps game to play, microtransactions are pretty bad but you can avoid those and it wont impact your enjoyment too to much. All in all, the game is definetly not worth the full price, but pick it up if you can find it on sale.
Summed up: There is nothing wrong with this game and half of the criticism isn't well grounded or just nonsense. That alone though, is not reason enough to buy it unless you are a fan of the franchise or already lack all other major FPS games. This is subjective, but compared to how Titanfall 2 _feels_ and how TF2 _flows_, the looks, the maps, pretty much everything, makes this game just about average compared to i.e. Titanfall 2. It doesn't feel like a triple A production, despite it being so. Maps in this game also feel super tight and graphics stale even on ultra with 100 FPS averages, but that's just my aesthetical taste and map preference. If you want the best sci-fi themed FPS you can't go wrong with Titanfall over this. If you want a military shooter then this is probably not for you.I thumb this up just to counter all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t reviews it's getting, despite people being disappointed in yet another CoD repackaging, it's just not proportional to this being a game that is THAT bad. It simply isn't. It's just not nearly as good as Titanfall / Battlefield. No even close.

it's funthe guns feel good, better than bo3the game feels smoothgets way too much hate then it shouldpick it up, it's pretty fun
It's Call of Duty In Space!  Nothing more, nothing less.The campaign looks like an ordinary CRPG nowadays, let's say Mass Effect. The only difference is - you don't have the dialogue wheel, but still there's gear customization, few things you can interact with on your star-but-not-star-destroyer, perks, and you can choose which and when to start side or main missions. Somehow this makes CoD: IW more of an RPG game than a lot of CRPGs. If you like those things set in the future, go for it.Multiplayer is CoD meets Titanfall - double-jumping-wall-running-fast-paced-shooting-things. It's not the best combo, but it works. There's a lot of things to unlock and work towards to, if someone likes to be regularly rewarded and grind those levels - here you go. The profile and character customization are an overkill, those shiny and badges with gifs, crazy colored weapons just look like the beginning of the internet. Just close your eyes, hear the modem sound and go for an adventure in the 90's...Is it worth buying? If you'll get your hands on it for 10$ or less - it's worth the price.
Call of Duty®: Infinite WarfareTop 3 campaign ever in CoD.Too much hate. Very underrated game.

I'm not sure I understand the criticism this game receives.I love the older Call of Duty games as much as the next person, they feel great and influenced the FPS gaming scene even up to now. This game is different to the old games, even more recent ones up to MW3, it's got your exo-suit mechanics that everybody loves to hate but honestly, it's exectuted fantastically.Overall, I think this game is a great improvement on the newer exo-suit formula, and stands out among the more recent titles from this franchise. While micro-transactions are present, they impact the game to a lesser degree than in a lot of other games as of right now.I would recommend this game to anyone who has enjoyed Call of Duty since BO2, or any similar franchises.

And there's a serious lack of players at times, making it hell to find anyone playing anything but TDM.The zombies mode is fun for a while and has a great 80's soundtrack. Definitely worth a shot if you enjoy CoD zombies!
*disclaimer*- I am a solo player, i don't like multiplayer, thus i didn't play at all to multi and my review is based solely on the single player campaign. - Yes i am aware that BF's multiplayer is so ****** better but, once more, multiplayer hits me one without moving the other.Sooo, that said, , i'll be straightforward : i loved this game and it is a good game but i recommand to buy it only at discount price !** Pros :- The setting, i loved it, classical Mars vs Earth or colonies vs old world. Kinda feels like a mix between Starlancer and the Expanse, minus the aliens.- Ethan, i mean .. Ethan ! I hate toasters, i hated them in MEs, BSG, and so on but Ethan is so well written and so far from the regular "killzzz all humanzz" that he feels like the most fleshed out (no pun intended) character of the story.- The graphics. They are good, with gorgeous sceneries, nice skins and very good animations (heyhey Bioware).- Fighter craft missions : i really liked flying a F22 lookalike in space with semi realistic newtonian model, drifting between structures/asteroids.- Spacewalk missions, nothing like infiltrating an enemy capital ship hiding in an asteroid belt, throwing away enemies with your grapple or fighting on a hull with mag boots !- Realistic weapons, all hail kinetic energy and boo the lazors because they are cheap SciFi and the devs didn't fall into the trap !** Cons :-  The campaign is very short and this is the reason why i said to buy this game on discount : 11 or 12 hours only to finish the campaign doing all (i don't think i missed any) side missions.- Enemy motivations ? Beside "killzz all Earthlingzzz" i didn't catch any, maybe i missed ? Not even a "colonial fools !" !! I mean nothing, absolute zero ! It is a waste of Kit Harington's talent.- The music ! I know there is music in this game, i've read about it but sincerly i don't remember it, at all.- Few months after its release the game is still plagued by the infamous crash at 1st mission loading screen : c'mon devs, can't you fix the anti-virus exception with a patch or you just don't care anymore and let players handle it by themselves ?** Conclusion : A good "hard" scifi shooter, but very short so buy it only with a very good discount !

Best Shader Preloading Simulator of 2017.11/10 Would Preload Again.
For those like me who looks for a good Campaign mode in a COD game, look no further. Infinite Warfare has one of the best campaigns next to the Modern Warfare trilogy. The story is well written, the characters are well voiced and you actually care about them eventhough as per COD tradition, everyone dies. The graphics are great and the space battles are what Star Wars Battlefront EA should have been. Optimization isn't a problem either in this game.
Disclaimer: This is a review of the Single Player Campaign only. I'm not big on CoD multiplayer. Also, I have finished this title previously on PS4, so please disregard my playtime as of the time I'm posting this review.So, I personally LOVED this game's campaign. Trust me, this was very surprising to me as I had previously not really loved a CoD campaign in forever. Some were quite decent, like Advanced Warfare, and some were horrendous, like Black Ops 3 and Infinity Ward's very own Ghosts.I was quietly optimistic about this game though, I actually liked it's reveal trailer. I thought it looked cool tbh and had no issue with the futuristic setting. In fact, I really liked that the vehicles, suits and weapons etc (absolutely fantastic weapon models btw, some of my favourites in any FPS) and thought they looked believably developed tech-wise from where we are now.The game has that bombastic, Hollywood blockbuster CoD feel to it, but it also allows more player agency than any previous entry in the series. In between main missions players are able to branch out from the main narrative and perform side ops, these allow for new weapons to be added to your arsenal and upgrades and new cosmetics to become available for your fighter jet, the Jackal. Many of the side missions, and main missions for that matter, allow you to fly this awesome bit of kit and it's a lot of fun, and nowhere near as "on-rails" as CoD usually handles vehicular traversal/combat.It's a really nice touch and makes the game feel far less linear than other entries in the series.The title looks absolutely exquisite for the most part as well. Sure, the engine does show its age here and there, and some textures don't stand up to close scrutiny, but overall, the presentation is almost always consistently excellent. I'd actually say Infinite Warfare looks routinely spectacular. Character models and facial animation is another area the title excels, perhaps only bettered by Advanced Warfare in the franchise.The story was enjoyable from beginning to end, and propelled the action appropriately. The antagonist is a little one dimensional but honestly, who cares? Your protagonist and his crew are a likeable bunch, in particular the wise-cracking robot Ethan, and the story actually has some surprising moments of gravitas that I definitely appreciated.In summation, I liked this title quite a lot. I cannot comment on multiplayer as I'm not qualified to do so, but the single player was a big win for me. I think it's unfortunate the game didn't get the reception I feel it deserved. Speaking for myself, I found the campaign in this title 1000x better than the manure that was Battlefield 1's campaign. Which was, in my opinion, such a boring collection of disparate stories cobbled together to form a fairly forgettable whole. It looked good, but that was about it.Performance wise, I have it maxed on settings at 1440p and running at an almost constant locked 125fps(the SP max refresh).However, I highly recommend Nvidia users do not use the most recent driver; 384.76. This driver was initially tanking my framerate hard, and was in some sections dropping as low as sub 20fps! After investigating, I found this was an issue many were experiencing. Rolling back to 382.53 seems to have completely remedied this situation and performance is buttery smooth

My review is based on the single player campaign.Having played all of COD campaigns I can safely say, that if this game is the furthest in the "future timeline" that the franchise goes, it was well worth it.There was a bit too much time in the cockpit for my taste but overall I really enjoyed it. The new cinematic cut scenes add a deeper level of emotional attachment to the characters than some of the previous installments. This is the first campaign with a bit of "choose your own path". You'll reach a point in the game where you can follow the main storyline or do side missions. If you liked previous COD campaigns, definitely buy this (when it's on sale). Side note: Audio is choppy unless you put it in full screen borderless mode.

Easily the BEST Call of Duty in years. Don't listen to the blind hater echochamber who seem to hate all things 'futuristic'.Infinity Warfare features:- Excellent epic space opera single player campaign with more side content than any other CODs entire campaign- Fun zombies mode with its own progression system and all new weapons have been added to the weapon pool so ANY player can use them!- Great multiplayer mode with a lot of variety in weapons, maps and character customization. ALL new weapons that are added to the game can be unlocked by anybody, not just those with the season pass.The microtranscation system is much fairer in this game than AW and BO3. As I mentioned, any new weapon can be unlocked through in game challenges. Variants can also be unlocked with salvage which is accumulated when you get duplicates in supply drops. This game is NOT pay to win. The base guns are extremely powerful and weapon variants simply add variety in the form of new playstyles with each weapon.Multiplayer is not as popular as other CoDs like BO3 on PC but I have no issue finding matches on the weekends at mid day, and any time throughout the week after 7pm. (I AM IN THE OCEANIC REGION)If futuristic combat doesn't scare you away, I highly recommend this game.
Single player: THe game is about 8 hours long.This is a game where seemingly 99% of the budget was spend on graphic artists. The modelling is incredible and the level of detail in areas where you just walk by once is insane. Certainly its worth buying when on sale simply because of the production level which is incredible.As for game play, I think its decent enough for a 8 hour game, but certianly would not work for a longer period of time as there is no real depth to it. There is no cover mechanism, and the stealth mechanism is really just a walk. All you do is shoot and throw various types of grenades. They add a few things like little robots and drones, but basically the shooting gameplay is the same from start to finish.About 1/4 of the game is played in the cockpit of a space fighter. Here the combat is basically identical in every situation and never develops to the point where its just boring.The multiplayer seems to be region locked and in my region its a ghost town and basically no one is there there.... so don't buy for mutltiplayer IMO because no one seems to play it.

I only play campaign and i like it. Very good shooter.
No regret buying this game
Finally something different! Infinite Warfare is the best in the series since the originals, bringing the series into the future is a great idea, it was time for a change as games like this were getting repeditive and lacked content. Infinite Warfare is almost 3 games in one package, as you have the normal FPS mode with amazing battlfield layouts, then you have the new and amazing "Space combat" taking off from the ground and into space, and then we have the Zombies DLC which is also Amazing, this game also has the best graphics around and I often find myself just stopping to admire the scenery. A lot of the enemies are robots instead of boring old human soldiers and they require tactics to destroy, like the excellent ability to "Hack" the enemies and take control of them! theres nothing cooler than being able to hack a robot and suddenly be inside it on the other side of the battle looking back at youself and taking out the enemy from the inside! after a certain time limit you can then self-destruct taking out as many enemies as possible, you also have the ability to call in a gunship to attack chosen groups of enemies, and you also have "Spider Grenades" that when thrown unfild into a mechanical spider that seeks out the enemy and then crawls up their legs and attaches itself to them before exploding. The levels are set up much better than previous games, its not just moving into a skinny area and shooting waves of enemies right in front of you and repeating, there is variety in the enemies and locations so you can flank the enemy or take them out from differnt vantage points, Shooting robot enemies is much more fun than humans, as the robots react so realistically to shots, seeing pieces fly off them and tearing them appart and if you take their legs out they will continue crawling after you, they also run at you in self-destruct mode giving you a short time to kill them before they get too close and explode, the Space Ship combat missions are a real treat and break the game up making it much more fun and completely changing the environment, combat & enemies, Flying the Ship is easy & it controlls perfectly, its actually so good that it could be a game on its own and even rivals games like "Elite Dangerous", so much effort and love has been put into this game, just like good old games used to be, COD Infinite Warfare is made like games should be, not just pretty graphics, this game has it all, it would be extremely hard to make this game any better, if you ever liked FPS games and have been bored with the constant copies and clones that offer nothing new then this is the game youve been waiting for! You wont be disapointed! and with the Space ship combat and beautiful looking Zombie DLC there is something for everyone in this game, My only problem is the story could be better, but the characters are very well voice acted and have a lot of personality, especially "Ethan" your team mate and Cyborg as he jokes "I carry the brain of a human farmer" "Really?" "No mam" They dont come much better than this! 10/10
The Story is great. Really doesn't deserve all the hatred. Agree its not like the classic CoD but its good alright.Black Ops 3 MP feels better but I would recommend this for the SP story & MWR!

This series has gotten so much♥♥♥♥♥♥ and I've basically stopped playing the series since Ghosts, but I decided to give Infinite Pew Pew a shot during this sale.Here's how I'll breakdown my thumbs-up despite the overwhelmingly negative reviews.The average movie ticket price in the US is around $8-9 and you generally get a little over 90 minutes of entertainment.Sure the franchise has run itself into a cycle of annual releases with the exact gameloops repeated over and over, but Call of Duty has consistently delivered an entertaining - albeit cheesy, over-the-top hoorah, pew pew mcpew-pew - singleplayer movie shooter.  I got my 9 hours of the ooh-rah space pew pew campaign. Played 20 seconds of the zombie mode before I noped the ♥♥♥♥ out of there. Was called a noob in multiplayer and then told my vicious namecaller to have relations with the corpse of his country's recently deceased head of state before quiting.  Yeah, I paid around $30 (in a thirdworld country so prices adjust a touch) with the summer sale for 9 hours of solid fun. Or about 6 movies worth of entertainment. Well worth the price in my book. Keep doin' what you're doing CoD, I'll buy it every summer sale... sure as I'll watch every damn Marvel, Fast & Furious, John Wick, and Transformer movie. They don't have to make sense or break new ground... they're just damn fun.Alright... time to give the last few CoDs a shot too I guess.

Decent game, don't understand all the hate!
This is worth at least one play through. Frankly, it is mainly worth buying just for the awesome Modern Warfare Remaster.The story is decent and the voice acting is good. The ending though is very anti-climactic to me and left me feeling dissatisfied. There is at least a bonus Easter egg for us F1 fans because Lewis Hamilton has a small part in here but let's just say acting isn't in his future...The gameplay was surprisingly bad. Every Call of Duty game has just about one level that makes you pilot a vehicle of some kind. These are always my least favorite. I don't buy first person shooters for crappy, low quality vehicle simulation experiences. I always push myself through the vehicle levels as quick as I can so I can continue on with the cool story and the first person shooting action. In this one however, there is a HUGE emphasis on flying a space ship kind of like in Battlestar Galactica. It isn't bad but like I said, first person shooter...not flight sim...The level design makes up for the gameplay though. The planets and moons that you get to travel to are amazing to see in person if you are a fan of space like I am.All in all, not a 'bad' game so worth at least one play through.

Base Game - Fluid, Fun, Fast-Paced, ABSOLUTELY STUNNING, decent campaign, enjoyable zombies mode. Personally I would wait for a sale or something, but if you just want a game where you can shoot a whole bunch of dudes mindlessly, this is definitely worthy of being in your library.MWR - ♥♥♥♥ing Beautiful, Balanced, Great Campaign, Great Multiplayer and Satisfying Gunplay. Overall the game is absolutely wonderful... when my framerate isn't eating dog excrement. I'm running a GTX 1080 w/ i7 6700K@4.00GHz and the game suffers from random massive frame drops and occasional freezing. I've messed around with every graphics setting, and even on the lowest settings it still has dropped frames in certain maps (especially Backlot). I have found no solution for this issue so far. Honestly, it's worth getting the Deluxe Edition of IW just for this, if you can get past the possible performance issues.
Should this be a COD game? No.This game is quite a hated game by a lot of people. But honestly it isnt a overall bad game. It makes the COD franchise look horrible just like the other 2 futuristic games. -CampaignThe campaign is quite interesting. First off with mission selection, selecting side missions to do before the main one. Another thing is the loadout selection that was introduced in BO2. The campaign overall has a decent story that is a little difficult to follow. Overall 8/10-MultiplayerThe Multiplayer is the same as BO3, same movement system, same over and underpowered weapons. But This Game introduces Weapon Variants, which are basically the same weapon but with perks. It gives weapons a new feel, but youll probably be killed by a NV4 or a Reaver Variant Overall 6/10-ZombiesZombies is my favorite part of this game. I have most of my hours on it alone. Zombies gives us an introduction to 4 new characters and a Narrator. The short before each Solo game gives an explenation on the whole situation, a must watch to understand. The gameplay is simple boots on the ground, theres plenty of fun things to do. I can't discuss the multi-player portion of Infinite Warfare, but I can say that I really enjoyed the single player campaign. It's not the best game as far as storyline goes, but it does have one that makes sense and is delivered pretty well. For sure the owners of GTX 1080 ti they don't have problem but keep in mind you have 11.3 Teraflops and the owners of SLI GTX 1080 have 18 Teraflops, as for the Vram 11GB and the GTX 1080 SLI owners 8GB even at SLI , as for the 1070 SLI owners they have 13 teraflops and 8 GB of VramBut the memory the Memory Bus Width at GTX 1080 Ti is 384 and for GTX 1080 and 1070 256..

You can't hate a game for its theme. Everyone judges this game because its futurustic but Infinity Ward did the futurustic theme right. I mean if you don't like the futurustic theme, just don't buy it but there is nothing wrong with this game. I don't prefer futurstic theme myself but still this game is fun and its really well optimized. Everyone says "multiplayer sucks etc." but there is really nothing to hate about it. Its CoD and everyone knows CoD has fast-paced combat but suddenly fast-paced combat becomes "worst CoD ever etc." and everyone suddenly thinks that Battlefield does it right and every other FPS games should do it like Battlefield. But thats compeletly wrong because Battlefield has some different style its compelety different from CoD. One has objective (conquest and rush mode) focused gameplay, slightly slow-paced combat, much bigger maps and the other has TDM (and some unique CoD multiplayer modes) focused gameplay, fast-paced combat, smaller maps, scorestreaks etc. I'm sure everyone hates this game because hating CoD is became a fashion these days. I bought it and i wasn't expecting it to be a good game because of all those negative reviews. But suddenly, i realized its not bad at all actually its pretty solid experience. I haven't played campaign yet but i played multiplayer and zombies. So far multiplayer feels pretty solid and zombies is aslo pretty good. They took a different road from Treyarch's zombies and its more colorful. I don't really say that there is nothing wrong about this game the price itself is a big negative and also that Legacy Edition is a big mistake but thats what Activision does its not developer's fault. So, what i'm trying to say is, if you like fast-paced CoD combat just buy it. All those reviewers bought this game for just leaving that negative review just don't listen to them they don't really play the game they just hate it no matter what.

I picked this up for $30 at my local Wal-Mart. I figured I'd give it a go for half price, why not? I'm not a fan of the crazy flying, jumping, cloaking of Advanced Warfare, but I decided it couldn't be too bad, and there's still a campaign and zombies modes.Well, the campaign was okay. It seemed really short and, if you skipped the side-missions, you could probably finish it in a few hours. I really wanted to like it, but it was way too forced and labored. It felt like a chick flick with robots. The ending was bland and poorly executed. The campaign had one excellent feature: The final notes from some of the side characters that didn't make it. Those did good at hitting you right in the feels, but the campaign itself was very lackluster.The one zombies map that's available without dropping another paycheck on DLC is pretty great. It does have tons to offer and hours of gameplay. Might even be the best zombies mode of any CoD game!There's a reason there are more people playing Black Ops 2 than this on multiplayer. No, it's not that Black Ops 2 has a good multiplayer. The multiplayer for Infinite Warfare is atrocious. You can only be effective after taking a whole bottle of adderall, as everything moves far too fast. Wall-running, sliding, jetpacks that recharge seemingly instantly...It's just too crazy. That being said, go contact your nearest kindergarten-age drug dealer and grab some Dew, it's time for a ♥♥♥♥♥torm of a party.6/10 - Do kinda enjoy multiplayer. Zombies is dank. Would buy on sale, but not full price.
Pro: - Outstanding Campaign.- Nice Graphics.- Weapon Variants.- Payloads and Traits.- Easier to flying around than BO3.Con:- Maps too small.- Bad scorestreaks.- Awful Shotguns.- Salvage earn rates are way too slow.- Laggy Multiplayer.- DLC (lol).7/10
Infinite Warfare is an okay game; not amazing, not great, not bad, not terrible, just okay. It isn't the best CoD game out there, that much is obvious, and the best probably goes to Black Ops 1, Black Ops 2, World at War, or one of the Modern Warfare games, but what do I know. What I do know is that this game isn't amazing, but it isn't terrible either, just okay. Campaign is fine from what I can tell, Multiplayer is okay, and Zombies is good, even if they copied a lot from Black Ops 3 (like the Gobble Gum system and a lot of the lines of dialogue from picking up power ups or the famous "Fetch me their souls" which is in Rave in the Redwoods).Multiplayer isn't as clustered or overpowered as Black Ops 3 with the infamous Brecci and D13 Sector. Speaking of, supply drops are much better in this game since you can actually get keys, not just Multiplayer, but from Zombies as well and you can salvage to just straight up buy varients, which for the DLC weapons, gets you the weapon; you don't have to unlock the weapon like in Black Ops 3, you just get one varient of that weapon or buy a varient using salvage from duplicates (and getting it from rare drops as a bonus like Cryptokeys) and you get that weapon.Zombies, while it does copy a lot from Black Ops 3 and Teryarch in general, it's not bad. It's hard as hell, fun with friends, and gets you keys, so it's very worth your time to at least try it out. Zombies in Spaceland, the base Zombies map you get with the game is insanely hard, but the other maps do get easier (which is typical for most Zombie gamemodes). Plus it gueststars David Hasselhoff, Kevin Smith, and more to come with the maps. Also, the main bad guy is voiced by Pee Wee Herman, just throwin' that out there.So, is Infinite Warfare a great game? No. Is it a bad game? Also no. It's just an okay game, it does not surpass the obviously better CoD games by no means, but is better than the obvious black sheeps in the series and most of the older titles, at least in my book. I say at least give the game a chance, if you don't like it, you don't like it, but that does not make it a bad game, it's just okay.So, in my opinion, this game gets a 6.6/10 because 7 seems too high and 6 seems too low.

**SINGLE PLAYER REVIEW ONLY**I bought this game very nervous of what the expect. I mostly wanted the Modern Warfare 4 Remaster, but since I got this thought I may as well give it a try regardless of the negativity it has recieved. I went in with low expectations and it turned into one of my new favorite games.Story: The story is pretty straight forward; save the Earth from an enemy looking to take it over. But I felt like it was more than that because the story telling in this game was great. It felt like the story for this game could be a far off future when we can finally accomplish space travel on the large scale. I connected with the characters and was deeply saddened as the storyline progressed further. It should be noted that I love science fiction and this game made me feel like I was playing a blockbuster science fiction movie.Gameplay: The gameplay is pretty standard and plays like any other Call of Duty game or FPS for that matter. The guns though were something that stood out for me. As much as I love science fiction, I am always concerned when I play a new sci-fi game when it comes to weapons. I don't like it when weapons go to futuristic that they don't seem realistic, but I don't like when weapons don't make a large enough jump from modern weapons to make them feel futuristic enough. This game hit a great balance of projectile and energy weapons with keeping them realistic looking. There are many space battle opportunities in this game as well where the player will pilot a Jackal and get in dogfights in space. At first, this was a lot of fun and I enjoyed it. Unfortunatly, after the fourth or fifth time, it started to feel like a chore and I didn't enjoy them as much anymore. I didn't outright dislike them, but the combat felt very slow, and I felt more disconnected with the characters and the story during those moments. Some of these missions are optional, and though I chose to do every one of them that I saw on the map, this obviously doesn't need to be the case for you. The game has a few moments where stealth is very much needed to complete a mission or get through an area easier. Though it isn't really required, going loud in these areas can be difficult due to the increased number of guys that show up all of a sudden. The stealth was nice to break up the run and gun, but was not necessarily implemented the greatest; but hey, it works.Graphics and physics: I'm combining these too since they are both short. I played this game maxed out in 4k, so needless to say I thought the graphics were amazing. Some of the space scenes looked as good as some I have seen in movies, if not better. The physics were done much like any other game so they were nothing ground breaking, but there were some space missions such as one on an asteroid where the asteroid is spinning and it made me feel like I was on a giant moving rock. Now maybe this doesn't fall under physics, but the way it made that entire mission play, felt like physics were at play at all times even if they really weren't.Conclusion: If you are looking for a good science fiction FPS, and are only looking for a single player story line to play through, then this is your game. I would highly recommend it to anybody looking to play this for single player only. I will not comment on multiplayer as I am one of the few that buys Call of Duty games for their single player and not multiplayer. Maybe that is stupid to some, but I have never been big on multiplayer in any game therefore it has never been my focus. Single player is what this game does do great though. My recommendation is to pick this game up on a sale as the single player campaign can be a little on the short side and definitely isn't worth full price just for a short compaign, but it's worth a play through at some point.9/10 I will replay through this again for sure.

This is the first Call Of Duty game that I have played, as a big scifi/space aficionado the setting was the thing that drew me in. It bought it purely for the campaign, and it was a really solid ten hours of quality scifi action. I liked it quite a lot, even though I'm more of a (A)RPG guy. Even the space fighter combat was pretty fun in spite of it being really simplified (coming from someone who has 600+ hours of space piloting in Elite: Dangerous).  On the technical side, I had zero problems and the game ran smoothly with a constant 60 FPS on max settings at 2560x1440 with i7-6700K & GTX 1070. The game looks really nice and the animation is really good. Definitely one of the best looking games to date.If you like Mass Effect, you're going the feel right at home here.

Sure some stuff is slightly annoying but overall I like the jumping / sliding in the game it isn't over the top like in CoD:AW and it doesn't feel like on chains like in BO3. The only thing that bugs me out a little bit is this supply drop bs and the Mark II weapons although I don't have anything against the Idea of Mark II weapons but Its a bit annoying that they give the XP benefit so you automatically play them even if you don't like the weapon as a whole.Altough I wouldn't recommend to get this game if you only have 2GB's of VRAM (If you have a NVIDIA Graphics card you can tweak the settings so it runs on 90 FPS on a 2gig VRAM card)Also there is a common bug which seems to occur very often, it doesn't allow you to connect to game lobbys anymore and always pops up an error message. This can be fixed by closing the game and clicking on "validate game files" under the Properties menu.

I bought Infinite Warefare for $29 today 5-19-2017 and i have 3.5hours clocked according to Steam. Now I was quite afraid to get this game on PC because of all the bad reviews about bad perfomance and this and that and also with the big 70GB download file size. But because of the free weekend thing (Multiplayer ONLY) I decided to download the game and see if my PC could handle it. First my PC set up:i7 4790K 4.0 GHZ (4.4ghz OC)Asus VG248 144hz 1ms monitorMSI GTX 970 (the card that ACTUALLY has 4GB of VRam)Z97 Gaming 5 Motherboard. 24GB of vengeance ramAnd Windows 10 64bit (with all the latest drivers and updated NVIDIA drivers)Now for my little review:The frame rate I got for Multiplayer was always around 85 to 95FPS (mostly 91FPS) and only a few times did the frame rate dip to around 40-50FPS at times when things got really crazy on screen with the action and stuff but that was ONLY a few times. 98% of the time for me I always got around 90 or so FPS. And the game never once stuttered. Never once crashed on me. Never once gave me ANY issues. And i got into multiplayer matches VERY fast. I was a bit surprised actually.  ALOT of people HATE the sci fi setting and futuristic setting and I respect how they feel but i LOVE the futuristic stuff i get a kick out of it. The zombies part I LOOOVED that a lot. Even as a solo player I LOVED how amazing the graphics looked and how much fun I was having. VERY VERY happy I made the purchase. Im so sorry to hear about those who are having so many issues. I guess im just a lucky PC gamer i dont know. But Im very much enjoying the game quite a bit. Also the campaign is a hell of fun for me. Again NO crashes NO stuttering NO frame rate drops. I get around 80-100 FPS depending on whats going on. But no issues at all with my system, And i only paid $29 for this game which is awesome. Anyways if ANYONE wants to comment on my review or ask questions feel free to.

Wall Running feels like it was forced in last minute, and wasn't meant for the game, which puts a damper on the quality of multiplayer, but it is still a fun game. Just totally surprisedFor a Call of duty game its actually alright, I know people gave this game hate because it wasn't the boots on the ground experience they wanted, instead IW made one of the best Call of Duty games I've ever played the campaign was beautiful with awesome cinematics and gameplay to back it up, the characters were three-dimensional in their own right adding a sense of attachment to them and their cause. for a Call of Duty campaign, this felt different to the others but in a good way. The online mode was actually pretty fun to play, although it was pretty hard adjusting to mouse and keyboard instead of a controller, it was fairly easy to get the hang of after a while. For those who are considering to buy this game I'd  strongly recommend it as it is one of the best Call of Duty games I've played, if you look past the boost jumps and futuristic crap and compare the overall product to other Call of Duty games you'll see that it's different but in a good way.

Undeservedly hated,  attempts to go on a different path than its predecessors, only to find the blind and albeit partially deserved prejudice of the community.As always, my experience reflects the singleplayer campaign and nothing more.So this is the last Call of Duty game (for now) on my amazing journey through the franchise. When the trailer released last year, I saw it and thought to myself: . Well the community and other gamers managed to make a record last year with Infinite Warfare, by having the trailer of the game being the most disliked video of 2016. Wow, that is actually impressive and kinda sad at the same time.I was cautious to buy the game. Did really this installment on one of my favourite gaming franchises reached the absolute lowest point? Has it really become that terrible? .I've been playing and loving Call of Duty ever since 2004. I loved the campaigns, loved the music, loved that summer-cheesy-blockbuster feeling you got for 6-7 hours, with awesome soundtracks and high octane action. The series evolved over the years. WW2 was scrapped for current and futuristic settings. Characters were developed (for the most part), stories become crazier (not always a good thing), but apparently this was the straw that broke the camel's back for the community.And you know what? It's a damn shame. Cause underneath all that blind hatred, lies one of the  and most emotional campaigns in the history of the franchise ever. With  actual character development,  (for some parts) gameplay,  vehicle combat and as always tons of action, weaponry, gadgets to use against the horde of enemies who come at you.I'm gonna start with graphics and say that this is absolutely stunning. Infinite Warfare is such a pleasure to the eye that I found myself exploring every nook and cranny of the game, being awed by the gorgeous graphics and post-processing effects and amazing sound. The game also gave me no hitches and stuttering and was actually insanely smooth on ULTRA settings. Gameplay is where Infinite Warfare dared to make a change and boy did it actually work. First of all, as the player you'll have access to your very own destroyer spaceship and that's pretty awesome in itself. From there you can select optional missions and jackal operations. Jackal is your spacefighter and the missions are essentially dogfights amongst the 'stars'. You might be thinking, hey isn't this an FPS game? Well it is but also you have these optional missions in which the game turns the formula of vehicle combat from the previous games, and actually improves upon it. The controls are so much better, albeit a little bit automated at times, there's a huge fun factor to the space dogfights and it's actually pretty beautiful to fly at super speeds through asteroid belts hunting down those SDF aces.Of course there's regular optional missions in which you board enemy destroyer and attempt to eliminate a HVT (high value target), steal schematics or rescue hostages. A couple of these are actually in outer space and these settings make for really interesting battlegrounds.As far as gadgets and weaponry go the game offers some really amazing things for you to have fun. Hacking modules allowing you to take control of enemy bots and initiate a self-destruct while their next to their friends, drones, instant foam walls to take cover, thermal scopes, anti-gravity grenades, seeker mines, double jumping, sliding and many more. I can't even remember the last time I had so much fun and felt so versatile in a Call of Duty game but Infinite Warfare has done it. The whole gameplay is so sublime that I was awe struck and perplexed from the universal panning of the game by the community.The story may be a tad cliche but it is done in a great way. Kit Harington (Game of Throne's Jon Snow) does an astounding job lending his face and voice to the main antagonist and captain of the  Rear Admiral Salen Kotch of the Settlement Defense Front. In the future where Earth has colonized Mars and other moons of the Solar System, the SDF act essentially as the enemy of the people of Earth. They are ruthless and relentless and you will feel actually incredible hatred towards them. The developers did an exceptional job into making characters that actually evoke emotions in the player.And what do you know, there's actual real character development in the game. So far as I'm going to say, it's by far one of the best I've ever seen in a CoD game, that it wasn't part of a trilogy (Modern Warfare). In combination with the spectacular cutscenes and in-game-engine events, along with non-linear elements such as reading personnel files on your PC on your ship, the many characters of Infinite Warfare expand well beyond whatever shallow supersoldiers who've come to expect from a Call of Duty game.And since some of us have a soft spot for robots, Ethan (E3N) was a pure delight to have aboard the crew. Make no mistake, this is not an RPG but there is lots of dialogue involved where characters become likeable or dislikable to the player.The game is also slightly longer than previous titles but it has a wonderful and sort of emotional ending when you put all the things in context.So where does Infinite Warfare fail? Well the dogfight mechanics do not leave too much room for anything beyond locking on a an enemy and pressing fire till they die, with the occasional countermeasure release. There are fun for the most part but do get a little boring towards the end. Thankfully there's not too much space combat to go about and some are optional anyway.Surprisingly my major disappointment was the game being short! As a CoD veteran, I should not really care. But you know what? The singleplayer is so good, the non-linear elements are there, that I was actually looking forward for  stuff to do. At times due to the brilliant settings of the mission, fighting in space, fighting against robots, all that futurism made me think I was playing Mass Effect FPS. I'm half joking but you know there's an air of something more than your average CoD game in Infinite Warfare.Which brings me to my final point. Infinite Warfare is probably the last futuristic installment on the franchise we're gonna see for a little while. With the upcoming release of Call of Duty:WW2, the franchise returns to its roots. It's both a good thing and a bad thing. Truth be told, you might be thinking that the WW2 environment has been done to death. And you'd be right. But at the same time, when was the last WW2 FPS you played? It's certainly been a while, right? Perhaps going for the 'safe' choice of going back to what made the franchise successful in the first place is what the community really wanted. It would certainly seem so from all the feedback this game received. And they would be right, but for the wrong reasons. I'm actually excited to see WW2 with modern graphics. But at the same time I'm also kinda disappointed that just where CoD was starting to spice things up with 'features' the community itself complained about for years, like non-linear gameplay, you have this very community shut the game down, quite unfairly. Again, I'm always talking about the singleplayer here, I have no interest in MP and the like.To cut a long story short, I'd say that if you're a real CoD fan, Infinite Warfare has one of the best campaigns I've ever played in the franchise. Yes I know, 'no true scotsman' and all, but for real, this was superbly done and the score it has on steam is in my opinion, utterly misrepresenting the great qualities in terms of gameplay, characters and fun the game has to offer to  FPS player. What the future holds for revisiting the WW2 in Call of Duty, well we shall wait and see.

It keeps saying that the update needs me to restart the game, but it happens everytime I restart.  The store is the only thing that can give me a little bit of information.  It'll start downloading the update, but then freeze to a "update needs restart" screen.  After this gets fixed, it'll be playable again. So, I'm going to start this off by stating that this if for the campaign only, because I gave up on Call of Duty MP way back with Ghosts.As for the campaign, what can I say?  It's Call of Duty.  The expected twists are there, the shooting is there....With the exception of the boost jumps and wall running, there's really nothing new added to the game.  Then again, with the fact they're putting out a new game every year (every 3 per developing studio), that's not really surprising.Ethan was an alright character, but as far as the characters on a whole, it really didn't jump out and say "ooh I must care about what happens to them", more like "well, I know you're going to die.Great that they can make these games look pretty, given they're given 3 years to work on them, so now how about working on, I don't know, maybe giving them some depth?  More character development other than "Hey, I'm here, care about me so when I die you might be affected by it"?Maybe in a minority on this, but I play most the games I do because I want to be entertained, and try and follow the story, and I wasn't bored to tears by it, but it's probably not one I'm going to go back to try and do all the side missions on it.  Probably won't even go back and play it again at all.The only reason I even got this was because I wanted MW Remastered, got it on sale, and managed to trade some things in so didn't even have to pay the full sale price, either, and even then it was barely worth the price of admission.But, I've only played theses since the original Modern Warfare, so what do I know?  Somehow, despite myself, even catching them onsale, I've still managed to acquire every CoD game since then.Only reason I'm putting recommended is because I can't do an in between, and as far as the actual game goes, it's not horrible, just not something I would rush out to play the day it came out (which I haven't done with a Call of Duty game in many, many years).
Even though the game isn't really the best COD and is getting a lot of hate i personally enjoy it and recommend it.

When they finally went to space, fans started to be afraid of aliens!!!... so they wanted back on Earth, in the arms of their mums, enjoying to play a century old conflict that has been turned on all sides by now. There will be nothing majorly new in the COD WWII game, but there was great potential in Infinite Warfare...It is a real shame that, like someone else already said in a different review, the community killed this game. I agree completely. I've played the Modern Warfare 1-3, but I didn't enjoy the story and presentation. I enjoyed Black Ops 1 more than 2, but they still didn't quite hit a chord with me.Advanced Warfare is when I started to feel so much joy in playing the COD games because the story, presentation and game mechanics really resonated with me. With Black Ops III, once I did understand the complex story (shame on those who dismissed BO3 for its "bad story"), I fell in love with the direction that the COD games were taking. I felt they were becoming more distinguished, more refined, establishing an interesting universe on which it could build on.And so they did, Infinite Warfare is in my opinion the MASTERPIECE of all the COD games. Better frames per second than most other COD games, even on my laptop. But the best part of this game is the story and the game mechanics. It is interesting, fresh, distinct and well acted.Shame on the COD fans with no taste!!! Infinite Warfare is an awesome game and I am saddened by the "returning to the roots" attitude that they wanted, because in a world of remasters and recycled stories, Infinite Warfare was new, maybe so new that these "upset" fans couldn't handle it. Let Battlefield 1 be what it is, because Activision/Infinity Ward had enough creativity to make their space setting feel unique.Real shame and I hope COD games will soon return to the setting that Advanced Warfare, Black Ops III and Infinite Warfare have taken !!!
Very well executed campaign mode. Loved the space setting. Ea(3)n made me smile.
Campaign is good and I'm not much of a multiplayer guy when it comes to COD (no hard feels ayyy), I liked the zombies mode and personally prefer sci fi and futuristic games compared to "boots on the ground" but be aware of the optimization issues, this game has some severe memory related issues and I'd say it's not the best port among COD games sofar.
Love the campaign. Hate the multiplayer.
great game the multiplayer sucks though i really like the zombies game mode its quite inovative
I only played the single player campaign (and have no interest in the multiplayer), so my recommendation goes to those who are looking for a good FPS set in a space marine background. And that is exactly what you get. It's an epic story, lots of herodom and hurrah, lots of weapons and bravado. Exactly what you expect. Animation and acting is top notch, graphics are very pretty, controls are good enough for the most part. I must say I really, really enjoyed the campaign, it's basically are very decent scifi action film.What's not so great are the space battles, the flight controls are more like baby's first spaceship, and the dogfight missions are more tedious than fun. But those are made up by some pretty fine ground battles and large levels.I bought the game on a sale, so take that into account. For its original price I would not recommend it. For anything under 20$, IF you are into single player campaigns, definitely get it. Lots of fun.
Doesn't deserve all the hate at all. Not as good as previous COD games like the modern warfare and black ops series, but not bad either. Really enjoyed the campaign and even the multiplayer and zombies mode as wel. Buy it in a sale tho
Everyone loves to hate advanced movement systems but I enjoyed this game the multiplayer while it was not populated it was fun. The zombies mode was refreshing and the campaign was cool.
CoD: I.W. is a good & fun game that is the most successful title of 2017 because it does a few things, & does them well. The action is tight & fairly thoroughly scripted. Dave Stohl, lead developer at Infinity Ward of this temporary project, must be very very proud of the work of the team on the game! The online play is well-structured. The singleplayer campaign gets you into that frame of mind & gets your blood pumping. This version of CoD has a sci-fi take on things that I enjoy, as I'm a fan of the Metro 2033 franchise & Doom franchise, also sci-fi in nature. Batman, too, but I guess that's not really sci-fi but more of a "hero fantasy" thing, I suppose. Without a shred of doubt I can say that Jacob Minkoff, lead developer of the CoD: IW temp work project, is very impressed with himself as far as how successful the game has been. Locations: The main character hangs out on a spaceship in a room with a bed & a computer between missions. He chooses his expensive spacesuit & semiautomatic weapon there. Then he is brought to places on different planets & completes temporary projects where there is a specific goal: to take a hostage out or to kill an enemy or perhaps regain control of a base. A national & international news corrospondent is included as a member of the group.Novelties: There is a thing that is new to this series that is very well done. The jet flying is AMAZING. You play several levels where you take control of a fighter jet, sort of like a TIE-fighter, and engage in firefights in outer space!!  If you have read a lot of military sci-fi books as a kid, CoD: IW is like a dream come to life. It's fantastically well done. I have read the whole "Ender's Game" series of books, and the "Dune" series, and that seems like something straight out of that lexicon. What I encountered of the flying was in the singleplayer portion of the campaign, & was not a multiplayer option, I'm sad to report.If you play a ton of FPS video games, you have a fairly specific vision of what constitutes good multiplayer, & CoD is IT! Years ago, the Unreal Tournament franchise sort of fit into that "AAA Big-Budget Blockbuster" slot, especially UT2004, & that was pretty fun if basically mindless free-for-all combat. That's OK, I get the idea that plenty of folks like that. The Battlefield & CS franchises I see as "not-quite-as-polished as CoD but still pretty good," & there is space for that in the market, for sure. VR games, I don't think so, no offense to the no doubt die-hard VR fans out there in the wilderness. Just too "gadget-y" at this point in timeNegatives: The double-jumping is irritating & gives the gameplay more of a comic-book feel rather than a mostly-realistic FPS experience that you can believe in. Basically there ends up being a lot of people jumping around super high in the sky, which just seems improbable. I understand that it is a fake video game world, so you have a suspension of disbelief & you are taking their rules at face value & just rolling with it. Still hard to believe in flying soldiers with no jet packs in sight. That kind of takes me out of the action a bit & makes me go,  In Crysis 2, which is fairly similar in terms of style & look & feel & so forth, there wasn't any of the "sky-jumping," even though there was some pretty weird weapons & some pretty wild costumes & definitely there were conflicts that were going on.Final Take: 8/10 stars, the sci-fi style is something new, & the action is still good otherwise. They play it safe as far as variety of gameplay modes goes but that is ok enough I suppose. The zero-gravity warfare is something new and you feel sort of like an army astronaut. Visiting a relative in New York City at the moment, the big Apple![edit] on a sad note, I've since deleted CoD: IW & have moved on to spending my spare time playing the video game RAGE, purchased in the summer 2017 STEAM sale

And it is personally the best zombies mode I've ever played. ( I don't like multiplayer ) The zombies in this game is unique, And the first where I've gotten close to doing the Easter Egg on. If you're going to get this cod for the multiplayer, think twice.

the game doesn't deserve the negativity it gets, sure its not your atypical Call of Duty, but its still pretty solid in quality to what you'd expect from a normal Call of Duty. The Multiplayer while fun simply cant connect to hardly any games (due to lack of actual playes...try Hardcore TDM that usually has the most traffic). To start off I will say I won't defy the hate this game get's, it is very similar to B03 and this is because I pesonally believe they put all their focus mainly on the campaign and zombies sections of this game.  Now the game itself Infinite Warfare is mostly solid, the zombies mode and campaign is easily the best in years.  Regarding Black Ops 3 zombies: This to me at least felt like you needed to do too much BS just to get to the Pack A Punch (This is where you upgrade your weapon in zombies), such as going to one area having to do certain tasks then finally being able to go to where the Pack A Punch was located. So how did Infinity Ward do it? They made their zombies mode a mixture of easer eggs for the diehard zombies player or new tryhard kind of player who wanted more then just surviving. But they also have made pack a punch easier while still keeping that slight challenge where you have to have to collect things to pack a punch. This is a great system for the zombies player whether their new or experienced as both kinds of players can do this without stressing out or quiting. What makes Infinite Warfare's zombies mode so fun to me is a mixture of things such as we finally have what I personally always wanted movie themed maps with completely different settings each time. Such as the first map no. 1 "Zombies in Spaceland" being set in a theme park with clowns as the mini event scene at 5 or 6 and then the boss scene at no. 9 or 10, (fyi Infinite Warfare does not call progression rounds or waves but scenes as it's movies oriented) and then you have map no.2 "Rave In The Redwoods which is a cool rock concert kind of place that has yeti's as the mini event and no particular forced boss like in the first map. This might seem disappointing to some or not hard enough but it works better by giving the player breathing room as well as figuring out where the photos are located to craft the boat that will take you to the pack a punch island. It so far is quite easily the biggest zombie map in Infinite Warfare but as I play on both console and PC I already know that the next map DLC map 2 Shaolin Shuffle is awesome and has yet again different music as well as it's event scene and spin on what people have come to expect with things such as wonder weapons. Now wonder weapons are a cool concept in Call Of Duty zombies, what they are exactly is something you usually have to work very hard for to get but once you get them their powerful and rewarding. In Zombies in Spaceland you had alien guns but like I said they were a good challenge to go for if you wanted that something more to work for. In Rave in The Redwoods you have this cool crossbow called Vlad and it is much easier to go for, by simply going to the pack a punch island and grabbing the sausages (yes that is no joke) from the bathroom near the pack a punch projector you would then almost feed certain mounted deer around the map following by then killing them. Anyways what I liked about this was once you did that it wasn't much more work to then get the upgraded version of the crossbow which was great. As for the incoming map for PC and Xbox Shaolin Shuffle the developers decided to change things again, and no not just the map or music but by adding actual awsome kung foo abilities which you could upgrade from challenges the best part of this was what I touched on about earlier, this map very much catered towards both new/casual players or pro players as you still had stuff like easter eggs but you had more cool stuff to do for the other players. Needless to say it was/is awesome this is by far the best zombies mode Call Of Duty has ever done it doesn't have a difficulty curve like Black Ops 2 and especially Black Ops 3 had. Which therefore gives you this more not holy hell difficulty but at the same time not a too easy difficulty. Mark my words if you think it's a joke get to scene 20 and you may well learn that it has both difficulty but actually still knows what fun is. On to the Campaign let me start by stating in my personal opinion this is my favourite call of duty campaign ever, it has difficulty, it has real true emotion and although it may have some really depressing parts it also has these incredible moments where you just are in awe. The characters are all very much diverse which I am glad Infinity Ward did having different races in the game makes it feel more real. This is your ship you choose where to go partially such as small side misisons that would give you bonuses for your sweetâ™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥jackal space jet or weaspons. The hub very much seemed like Mass Effect which is great that they tried to do something similar (but sadly not near the same detail) to that, if only the Call Of Duty development teams could make their games actually be more like this. As having actual control such as being able to choose missions and just wealk around my ship was great I just feel at the same time it could have had so much more if they had more time. The way you would pick your loadout was fantastic and I sadly wish multiplayer had something like that, the side missions although not large were still great fun to do for something else, as for the mains story it was truly epic and emotional. I won't spoil it for anyone who has yet to play it but it truly was something that I felt was unexpected for Call Of Duty campaign's. It's just like I said they need more of that do what you actually want to do kind of thing in the call of duty campaigns as it was a good start but maybe actually go crazy next time, as great as it was there were the typical limitaions one comes to expect in this franchise which saddens me. A last note for those curious Kit Harington was a good villain but he needed to be in it more I felt. The character you played was great just like your best friend was, very much  superb as I hoped. On to Multiplayer now the hardest thing that breaks my heart. I'm going to state that I very much felt like with the effort the other two modes had being zombies and campaign I feel if the call of duty development teams such as the one that made this game being Infinity Ward had more time, like another year multiplayer could have been better then it turned out being. Which is why I believe Activision need to have another team that makes new projects or work on things such as the call of duty franchise, then each studio has 4 years which to me is the sweet spot for games such as these. I do realise that gets expensive. Multiplayer:You pick a robot like character it looked like, you have special weapons and abilities which is not call of duty like in the slightest and as the same with B03 I disliked it. There are weapon variants which I do actually like that give your weapon more options and yes this system was improved much since AW, their supply drop/Quatermaster system just needed more work. But there is very little customization, for those who played Advanced Warfare it was great but has been terrible since Black Ops 3. The weapons and maps are the only good things about this multiplayer as apart from that I didn't have much fun playing the mode sadly. Weapon choice I can definately was like AW in the regard you had fresh new weapons and the old classics such as a future AK-47, Ak74u, M4A1,other SMG'S as well as other great choices such as new energy based and balistic based ones like the Mauler. It definately was nice to have free dlc weapons that for those without the season pass you just had to do a challenge to unlokc them which I hope is a feature added to future COD games. Maps were beautifly designed and are fantasic to which worked greatly, I just wish they kept events for maps like COD ghosts had as it would have helped sales.
2012 to 2016: Call of Duty : It's just a name.

Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare is definietly one of my favorite Call of Duty games. I am a sucker for sci-fi games, and I gotta say this game is really fun.The multiplayer is really fun, fast-paced action with a lot of ways you can customize your play-style. Althought I really dislike the sniper rifles, they just seem odd to me. You can do missions that give you some rewards and they aren't even that hard. The cons about the multiplayer tho is that not a lot of people are playing it, leading to a long search time.Performance wise this game runs decent. The only thing that is bugged is the FOV option. It is not optimised and tweaked well, when you start a map the camera will go through the walls and it doesn't show a big problem, it just triggers your OCD.The campaign I have yet to play, but I have heard from some people it is pretty good. I will update this review when I finish the campaign.
A well done campaign. Zombies are decent. Multiplayer is OK. TDM is the only online mode you will be able to find populated, aside from that there are random FPS drops and some texture glitches, but i only found this in the multiplayer. Haters gonna hate, but i definitely found myself enjoying this one. If it goes on sale and you got some extra dough, try out the campaign.
